I love Asian fusion and had to try this place out! We had a Groupon deal so our party tasted lots of their menu items for a reasonable price. This review encompasses our overall experience and also the quality of the food.

On the day I went (Friday night at 8pm), this place was a solid 3 stars.  At 7:45-8pm, it was really crowded, which I think was because of a large party.  This group probably was probably the reason for the slow service we experienced as well.

I like to normally give a place a second chance but not likely with Kombu Kitchen.  They were horribly understaffed.  Two servers who doubled as the managers and the bartender.  We checked in for a lunch reservation and immediately I was turned off when he cleared our table by wiping the table down with his bare hand.  Yes, you read that right.  I will give them credit they tried their best but it wasn't good enough.  We ordered some sliders to start and a couple entrees.  My friend's entree came out first and mine came out after the sliders which came after her entree.  Both were pasta dishes.  Her gnocchi came out gummy but strangely flavorful. I ordered what I thought to be a risotto with peas, artichokes, and asparagus.  What I got was Risotto with Peas not a single artichoke or asparagus in sight or taste. Tasty strangely enough but not what was advertised.  My friend also wanted to confirm her check in on open table so she could get points and the server asked "Exactly how does Open Table work?" Really this day and age people still have this question? Even worse someone who works in the restaurant.

Had an awesome dinner last night here! Chef Kristen even came out to greet us and offered up a sampling of their delicious truffle fries. The Gnocchi was so good! I also had one of the best Moscow  Mules I have had in a long time. The views are amazing and the food is superb. I can't wait to return!!
I walked into what used to be Blu with a friend of mine and could not have been more overjoyed with the changes that Kombu Kitchen has made.

There wasn't anything I enjoyed about this cafe/restaurant. I refuse to even go to the restaurant because the prices for the cafe are out of this world expensive. The food is alright, nothing great or nothing too terrible, but it's not worth half the money they are charging for it. Also, there wasn't one staff member who was nice to me. Everyone seems uninterested in helping the guests, like it was a chore to give me the food that I ordered and paid for. I would not recommend this to anyone.

I came here today with the sole intention of proving everyone wrong and rating this a stellar five stars. I was convinced the world was butt-sensitive to ambiance, and I was here to prove them all wrong.

One star is pushing it would give 0 if yelp would let me.  First lets start about how rude they were before my workout.  Wanted to grab a juice and snack couldnt get anyones attention and when i finally did they acted like i was bothering them.   The food sucked...no flavor what so ever....threw it away and the juice was warm.  So after a few days tried it again at the bar wanted the sliders heard they were good.  Don't always believe what you here...dry, dry, dry, and the slaw was bland.  I think that the service and management are the worst things about this sorry excuse for a restaurant.   From the chlorine smell to the lack of service it is one place i will never try again

While standing in the elevator confused, I was told that Kombu Kitchen was on the exact same floor as the gym at this address, which explained why everyone was dressed to increase their heart rate, instead of sitting down for a meal - story of my life.

This review is for the Deli/Cafe, I didn't try the restaurant because if they can't get "fast" food right, why bother to try "fine" dining?! First, I had to wait for an elevator, then right out of the elevator, I was hit with a heavy smell of chlorine permeating from either the gym pool or water feature, next I actually saw a hotel guest in a robe & bare feet, followed by members in sweaty gym shorts filling up water bottles. After too long of a wait, I finally received my boring mushroom omelet,  no sides, okay if I wasn't paying these high prices (which since they're in the four Seasons building,  I guess they feel they can get away with), but there are many other better options in the immediate area. The mushrooms tasted chewy & "earthy" and not in a good way.  Illy coffee, which I usually love,  was bitter. I'm giving this place one star only because the sweet guy working behind the cafe counter was a savior, very pleasant, working hard & trying his best to make up for the stuff out of his control. The sports club seems to place their focus on the gym, not the food; I suppose this place is meant merely to be a convenience for members to grab some water or a smoothie after a workout, but it's not worth the elevator ride up for an outside customer.

My salmon bowl was super flavorful. Quinoa has never tasted so good, and they get their fish fresh in daily. Great healthy options, awesome service and one of the best views on market street. I will definitely be coming back for the happy hour.

In a nut shell, lousy, lousy, lousy management.  Staff is unorganized, they know they are not running well and they blame each other for the many service failures that appear to happen with regularity.
Thank goodness good food is back to sports club LA. Great healthy choices good portions and tastes great
Nice service, good food. Love fish balls, side order broth with sauted shrimp. Seafood noodle is another favorite.
Good food, and reasonable price

There's always a line at this restaurant and because of that I really wanted to know what the hype was about. I came here with a group of 6 hungry coworkers and all of us ordered different types of food. Some ordered pho, some ordered rice plates and some ordered vermicelli bowls. I was one who ordered a vermicelli bowl. My coworkers and I are people who would eat everything and not waste any food.
I really want to like Sai's pho but every time I come here, the broth taste way too plain! I catch myself drenching sirracha and hoisin sauce every single time.
Food is as good as other Vietnamese places in the area. But the service is just terrible. And yes never talk to the owner on the cash counter. He is just a super rude frustrated soul.

Okay, okay. I came back for some pho and I have to say, it was pretty damn good. Huge heaping hot steamy bowl with shredded chicken and more bean sprouts than 3 bowls could handle. Typical Asian service where getting a straw and a cup of ice or your check is greater than or equal to working in a coal mine, but c'est la vie!
My first time eating here, highly recommend. I like this restaurant for a couple of reasons:

They are very fast, so even if there is a line, you will be seated relatively promptly.  I had the beef pho today and it hit the spot.  The broth was flavored well and the beef was still tender despite being fully cooked in the soup.
Can't believe Sai's averages below 4 stars! Great, authentic Vietnamese flavors and dishes in FiDi, ample seating, speedy service, good prices. What more can you ask for??

This place has the best Pho I've ever had - I wish I could steal the recipe so I could make it at home!  Great lunchtime spot although it gets busy, but I've never had to wait longer than 15 for a table.  The place is small and seems to be family-run so service is always great!  Full Disclosure: I exclusively have the Chicken Pho here and haven't tried too many other dishes.
Came for dinner and tried the curry beef stew noodle soup. I don't know if I will ever try anything else because it was that good!!!! Huge portion too!  The server was very nice and polite.
Gross. I've been here before and it was generally decent, but I came back since Pho Hoa is closed and this is the only other pho place I know of in the area.
I've walked past this place a million times and finally decided to give it a try.

Came here for solo lunch. The restaurant was busy but I got seated immediately. Thought it was great but the good thing ended there.   As soon as I got seated I see the workers were shouting in Vietnamese (to be accurate, a man was shouting at a woman) and I was told to move to a different table. Moved to a second room which is much warmer. Them the same yelling guy came and started yelling again at the woman. I see two people with the food (which a half way done) and told me to move!  I finally said "are you kidding?!"

Definitely a fan of Sai's. Get here before 12 and you and your party will get a table. On a weekday, at exactly 12, the house was full! Nice family run place. Service was always polite and generous but food takes a while to prep if there's a lot of people.

I really enjoyed my #80 with Pork. This is a Vermicilli Bowl with Pork and Imperial Rolls. I love Imperial Rolls! The place was packed with a line outside, The service was good and they did not rush you. I have passed this place hundreds of times and I am so glad I finally went in!
Claypot rice is awesome!

This is my third time here for lunch, two times dine in and once to go. The food isn't fancy, but nice and homey and really hits the spot. I'm especially find of the noodle soup with tomato and crab! The portions and menu selection are a good for a downtown eatery; light eaters can probably share an order.
I eat here at least once a week and love it!

This is one of the places my coworkers and I go back to frequently.  The curry fish noodle soup is absolutely amazing.   The first 3-4 times I went here, I always ordered the same thing.  I've been branching out and trying some of the other dishes, such as the crispy noodle dishes, etc, and have been generally pleased with each choice.
Their bun rieu is def. my comfort food, esp. during tough work days. Ventilation does need some work. Avoid long line at lunch hours.

3 stars for the food being just OK. I'm from San Jose (home of Little Saigon) and I've had wayyyyy better Vietnamese food and for cheaper! Although they have a nice variety of authentic dishes, it is more of Chinese fusion restaurant to me.
Got the curry noodle soup that everyone was raving about, but the lamb version, because...who can say no to lamb?
I found a Vietnamese version of Burmese Oh-No-Kow-Swe!!    Curry chicken noodle soup!

I was in the neighborhood for business and chanced upon Sai's. It is a interesting setup, looks like they took over 2 stores and combined the 2, there are two separate rooms with a door connecting the two.
Sai's is a little gem - a great inexpensive Vietnamese meal in the financial district.
Skimpy on meat with a lot of vegetable filler

I honestly don't know why this place only has 3 stars on Yelp, but I kinda want to keep it that way. Don't get me wrong, it's not because they have bad food, bad service or vermin. IT IS BECAUSE THEY ARE THE BEST KEPT SECRET IN THE FiDi!!!! I have ordered most of the non seafood items on the list and I have yet to be disappointed. My order is always correct and I always get service with a smile even when things are crazy.

I've been to this place 20+ times and every time I leave I wonder why I entered in the first place. Terrible service and the food is mediocre at best. No reason to go there when chinatown is a block away. Only thing to expect there is a long line, a long wait, and terrible service.

When it's rainy outside, I usually like to have noodle soup. I decided to go to Sai's (had it once before and it was decent). This time, I opted for #17 Seafood Noodle Soup. It was just what I needed. I'm particular about my broth because some places either water it down or they do the complete opposite - put waaaay too much additives like MSG that make me nauseous and have the absolute worst headache. But not this place. The broth was just right. There were lots of veggies and the seafood was clean. The shrimp was already peeled (yay!), there were little slices of fish cake, fish balls, slivers of cuttlefish. The bowl itself is quite large, but I don't usually aim to finish all the soup. Definitely will return. I went around 1:30PM so the crowd already died down and it was just me.

I used to like this place, despite the uncomfortable seating, noise and poor service...  Until one day I got served a meal with... roaches.  Yes, there were several roaches floating inside a huge bowl of chicken noodle soup.  They looked like fried onions...  But those weren't onions, trust me!  Onions do not have legs...  The server treated it like nothing happened.  He apologized and offered to bring something else.  When I declined, he still charged us for the roach broth!  Glad they didn't charge extra for the roaches.  Later I learned about their very low food inspection score.  One of the worst in the city.  It was even published in a local paper, SF Chronicle, for it's low safety score.  The way people describe it recently makes me feel that things are not improving.  Personally, I am not going back to that place if I was dying of starvation.
------ updating for last 4 years -------------

Been meaning to pop into Sai's for about three years now, ever since my first job in the big city (onto job numero dos), when I walked by it every. single. day. Though I'm now about five blocks away, I finally made it inside.

Had the pork lunch combo for $11.00.  Also comes in chicken and beef.  Combo has rice, prawns , imperial roles, slaw and tea.  My buddy and I shared a table with a nosy couple who listened in our conversation as we made up fake outrageous stories.

In one sentence, Sai's is one of those restaurants that falls into the group of "I would only go there if I'm stuck in the area" category. They collected the stars on Yelp by 1) people who work near by so that Sai's is their Vietnamese lunch choice and 2) people who never been to Vietnam but thought they had the best Vietnamese food in the US.

Whenever its a busy day at work, my co-workers and I are always eating from Sai's - it's our favorite restaurant! We are so happy that Sai's is only 1 block away - we can order from Sai's everyday if we like (and sometimes we have).  Over the years, I have tried many of their dishes - all are excellent - and my current favorite is the 80 with chicken - which is the vermicelli bowl with chicken and imperial rolls.  Sooo good.  I also really like the Banh Xeo (the crispy crepe).  Also, on a cold day, my all-time favorite is the Bun Cary Ga (curry chicken noodle soup) - which is totally delicious and it warms me up quickly.
Got introduced by a friend today and really enjoyed the Curry Lamb noodle soup. I didn't enjoy removing the bones. Maybe I'll go with curry chicken next time.
This hole in the wall is a true SF hidden gem. If you have never had vietnamese curry pho, then you have to go to Sai's.

I came here for lunch with the Boyfriend and his mom last week and I was honestly skeptical as they were walking me through the door. I'm kind of picky when it comes to my Asian food venues. It also didn't help that Boyfriend mentioned that this place had previously had a rodent problem? I mean, nothing necessarily looked out of place and nothing was overtly dirty -- at least, no more than you would typically expect at such an establishment (I know you know what I'm talking about).

My biggest concerns with this place were (a) the wait and (b) cleanliness.  I was pleasantly surprised with both.  As to the first point, a party of 2 at 1145 = hardly any wait.  It was really, really crowded though even at that time, i.e. slightly before the lunch rush.  By the time the lunch rush started, the wait looked insane.  There were lots of small tables so I bet smaller parties have an easier time than bigger groups.

The location is easy to get to, also it has ample seating and is well maintained. The service is good i.e. very good. And you are greeted by a large selection of pizzas types to choose from. The Pizza slices are generous,however the crust is off. Its a bit to hard and flaky it does not have the texture or bend a traditional NY Pizza has. Still it's good enough and worth a try.

Excellent value and quality in the FIDI. Italian style food. Each day they have a rotating daily special. I like lasagna Wednesday. The salad bar is stocked fresh as well as a hot bar that changes a little bit daily. They also sell big slices of pizza and calzones for a great price. I am a big fan of the pepperoni mushroom calzone. I will eat here 2 to 3 days a week when I work in the area.

I haven't been here in a while but the pizza is good! However the service was terrible!! I am greatly disappointed as I ordered slices of pizza for my daughter and I. Our server just looked at me and I waited till she at least greeted me! Which is seriously rude and she acted like she didn't want to take my order!! Won't be coming back here!
We've been here twice. The first time was awful so we waited a year and tried again today.

Not too much to say about this place. It's a pretty good lunch staple around the Embarcadero for people working in the area. The food is reasonably priced, and portions are pretty decent. You'll see a crowd anywhere from super huge construction workers to those sassy office ladies working in the nearby offices. There is ample seating but that means nothing during the lunch hour rush.

Everytime I walk by this place it smells just like a great pizzeria should, unfortunatley I was not impressed, got a slice of good ol' cheese and it was lame, crust just tasted wack to me. Got a caesar salad too which wasnt too bad, they at least tossed it fresh for me. If I ever do return it won't be for the pizza.

I've been going here at least once a week for a long time and I've never had a bad lunch here - high quality food and friendly service.  Good value for lunch in the FiDi.  Very clean buffet and everything tastes great.  I love the fresh hot pizza slices and all the soups are great too.

Been here twice.  Once for pizza-decent. Once for a meatball sandwich-no thank you (salty sauce, mushy meatballs, mushy bread, and powdered parmesan cheese).  I'm told there are better cafeteria style places in the FD.  Skip this.
Quick lunch spot w/ good deals. You can choose from combos such as salad w/ half chicken, salad w/ half sandwich, salad w/ pizza - all priced around $7.50-$8.50.

In SF on business, I have no intel on restaurants around my office so I tried this place out of convenience. It looked like a pizza joint from the outside but I was happy to discover that they had other offerings.
Cafeteria food make in bulk
Good place for lunch decent salad and entree bar, reasonably priced.  The salmon is really good!
Soup Nazi!

This will definitely be a new go-to for lunch after a coworker recommended it. I had been going to a different spot for pizza but they didn't have the combination of pepperoni and sausage readily available.

Decent salad bar, but the rest of their food including the pizza, is only adequate. With all the new places opening up in a two block radius of Portico, it wouldn't take much effort to get something much better. One thing to watch out for at this place is double charging.. this has happened multiple times and is a complete inconvenience to rectify. The most recent one was a large order for a company lunch - how  dense can their staff be.

This is my go to place for lunch in the FIDI...the hot/cold salad bar has plenty of options for everyone (although the cold salad bar does not change that much) and it's quick for self serve if you are in a hurry. Their sandwiches are average, not too bad. It's not the cheapest around but pretty average for FIDI and relatively healthy.

Went here for a quick easy dinner today and was greatly disappointed. It was only a bit over 4 dollars for a slice of pizza and a soda, but the pizza was terrible. Everyone at my table agreed. And usually I love all sorts of pizza (homemade, frozen, dominos, gourmet) because they each have their own merits. But this was just nondescriptly bad in the taste and texture. Reminded me of the pizza in high school before we got pizza hut.

This is one of my go-to places for grabbing a quick lunch at work. More important than the great food, decent prices and ample seating is that it's *fast*. Need a quick slice? 2 minutes. Want a salad? As little or as long as you like. For those of us who get a minimal amount of time on a lunch break, this is a lifesaver.
It makes me so incredibly happy that the nearest restaurant to my school includes a salad bar. THANK YOU!

I like Portico for: (1) serving tasty food; (2) fair price; and (3) buffet style menu, on top of the pre-planned menu. You can get a tasty meal under $5. Pizza is not the best (especially coming from NY ;)) but their slices are large and they have a good variety. The hot bar and the salad bar both have a good variety of food selections. Also make sure you get their loyalty card, if you visit Portico regularly.

I only come here for the pizza which I believe is the best in the area. It gets really busy at lunch time but the pizza line goes by in five minutes and that includes waiting in line, ordering, heating-up the pizza then paying. $4 for a really big slice, not too bad for the area.

I live right next to it n never ate here for the longest time! I thought the pesto pizza was delish. Very inexpensive, the place is super busy during lunch time but line moves fast and efficiently! Good place to go get a slice of pizza. No complaints.
Portico is such a good lunch option. The pizza isn't gourmet, but the slices are big, cheesy, and pretty darn tasty. I have never eaten here and regretted it.

I'm not amazed by the food but it is good. Slice of pizza and a small salad for under $8, cant go wrong there. They do accept Square at the salad register which is a welcomed payment option. All in all, I would eat there again.
Great for when you're in a bind. Interesting mix of people here. I recommend sitting at the counter looking out the window so you can make awkward eye contact as you're chowing down on grub.
I swung by here after striking out at Mixt Greens; next time I'm craving salad at work I'll just start here. It's pretty much Lee's, but with pizza instead of Chinese food.

Portico's is the ultimate healthy lunch buffet.  They charge you by the combined weight of your items. The salad bar is impressive, so you can go crazy but then be prepared to be shocked at the price of the salad you've created.  Broccoli and beans can get heavy!  Their complimentary bread (they put in your bag after purchase) is delicious.  I suspect it's the same recipe as their pizza dough. The pizza is just alright. Their other hot items include soup, pasta that changed daily, salmon and another type of changing protein.  All very tasty.  The staff is also very friendly and know me well by now.

After being bored with going to the same places for lunch every day, my colleagues and I decided to go to a new place. While walking along Mission St, we encountered this seemingly popular lunch place. With a large space nicely partitioned into a large salad bar, a soup stall and a sandwich stall, this place seemed like a good bet for a quick on the go lunch. While my friends indulged in their meats and chicken, I, being a vegetarian, was left with a single sandwich choice. And unfortunately, that sandwich was nothing special...just a bunch of veggies strewn between two slices of bread. "What else do you expect?" you might think. But after eating gourmet sandwiches at the Sentinel and Working Girls, I found it hard to ingest this simple standard sandwich. I wish there were warm vegetarian sandwiches...anyhow, this rating only reflects that single dish that I had. I will probably come back again some time to try the salad...and will update the rating if it's any better.
This place seems rundown and with a little bit of remodeling, this Portico could be a much better spot to hit up for lunch!

Portico is my go-to for lunch just around the corner from work. What's appealing to me is that it's fairly inexpensive and the fresh salad bar is exactly what I go for. There's just about everything you would want and need in a salad, along with toppings and quite a handful of other lunch items you would desire on a given day. Chicken, salmon, some sort of seasonal dish, veggies or specials are all available as hot-plate foods.
Came in here around 3 for a slice of combo, expecting it to be old since it was way past lunch time.
Portico is a restaurant with pizza and buffet style food.
Standard bland, doughy, San FranSysco pizza or your choice of steam-tray Italian.  I wonder if this place used to be a Sbarro.  At least it's cheap and fast.

Fresh, plentiful. Just good. You can have something different every day. Everything is really good. The pizzas and salads are great. The prices are right too. For convenient healthy lunch at a great price, this place cannot be beat.

I was craving pizza big time and since this place is so close to the office the smell of the food drew me in. Although nothing beats east coast and New York pizza, not bad. They take credit cards too thru the square app.
The way a buffet should be!

You're talking about being in the Financial District and wanting something cheap to eat. Well this is the place. Today was my first time in this restaurant. Although I didn't explore the whole thing because the pizza look so good, I know they have salad there as well. They sell pizza by the slice. I got the pepperoni and mushroom slice for $3.60. It's a pretty big slice of pizza. They have it out for you to pick and then they throw it back into the oven for a minute to reheat. Service is fast. The men behind the counter are very friendly. It was a good pizza
Price: 4.5 stars
Typical situation.
Pizza slices are huge, salad bar is fresh with a ton of options. Hot food on the buffet can be hit or miss. Staff is freindly. Quick, easy lunch.
Open late with great pizzas and beer.  I was shocked to get a deal on a slice and good on tap brew in the city.
Another entry in the "order food for work" series, where I look for ease of ordering, ease of delivery/pickup, and taste of the food (of course!).
Waited 90 minutes for a truly disappointing pizza. I mean really average. I think there's a million other places to get better pizzas from.

Best pizza in town in my opinion. Affordable, nice people, and the food is consistently amazing! They have a punch card: 7 slices and the 8th is free (which makes it even more affordable). They have the most important SF brew on tap (Anchor Steam)! I have been coming here for over a year now and I have yet to have a bad experience. Their employee Vincenzo always has a smile on his face and makes sure that customers get exactly what they need; he exemplifies what great customer service requires. It seems there is a real cohesion with all of his coworkers, and that's what makes a team! I will not stop coming here as long as I am in SF and even if I move away, I would definitely make it a point to enjoy a HUGE slice of New York style pizza. Whoever owns this place knew exactly what the Financial District needed in the way of pizza and service, hats off to ya.
Great New York style pizza !  Hand tossed with fresh mozzarella , pepperoni sausage and the slices are worth every bite !
Pretty good pizza. I definitely like the Pesto and Cheese pizza when I want a little flavor on my pizza.
Healthy escape.

The You Say Potato is awesome and the portions are huge. One slice of pizza is plenty to hold me for a while. they have some other flavor combinations that look delicious as well. All that being said, I can't help but feel that it's missing something. I don't get that insane pizza feeling that I do when eating at the tip-top spots but I couldn't put my finger on what exactly. Still, a solid, delicious place but with all the amazing pizza joints in SF, they have stiff competition.
First impression when you walk in, is that of dust. Thick, dirty dust covers the walls.

This pizza is pretty good, i ordered a slice of the meat lovers pizza...it had a thin, crunchy crust, the right amount of sauce and cheese, and some really good sausage. Location is great for workers in the area...parking sucks...and the workers in there werent exactly customer service oriented...they looked like they hated it there. But i gotta say a pretty damn good pizza
I've been eating at Escape From New York a lot lately and realized the 3 Stars from my previous review doesn't really do it justice.

I'm quite confused looking at these pictures of awesome looking pizza...because their pizza doesn't look like that. Like all of the other EFNY locations I've been to in the city, they skimp on toppings. They have the weakest mushroom slice I've ever had. Weak on mushrooms. Weak on cheese. Another strike against em: they don't have a decent veggie slice. I'm not a vegetarian, but I love veggie pizza. They don't have a "veggie slice." They have a greek type thing, and they sometimes have a pesto slice, and the aforementioned weaksauce mushroom. I could imagine this would be a pain for someone who actually is a vegetarian. The slices that include meat also tend to be skimpy, and they have the floppiest crust, ever.
I had a slice of the fig, bacon, cheese,and some sort of balsamic reduction. It was fantastic
A million years ago, I used to love the EFNY on the upper haight. The pizza was simple, and good. And it tasted like authentic NY style crust. I haven't been to that one since then.

I have to say I've been having issues finding consistently good pizza in San Francisco and Oakland. Even the Escape from New York Pizza place in my old hood in the Haight wasn't that good. I'm from the east coast where you live and die by pizza and I just didn't understand how pizza could be bad. Anyway, I found this spot near my job and the pizza is passible, plus the chicken parm sandwich is pretty good too. So unhealthy and fast but GOOD! Thank goodness!

I was looking for the bus when I stumbled upon this gem. I was hungry and decided to stop in for a quick snack. It was absolutely delicious. I was hard to order when I saw all the options of pizza they had. The staff was very fun and happy to serve. The enthusiasm was contagious and the slice was very scrumptious.

I ordered the Elementary My Dear Watsonville and it was delicious & fresh. Delivery was speedy too. My only minus one star is that the delivery guy dropped it off at the next door office instead of following my instructions to knock on my door to deliver. Kinda weird, but it was still good. I'll order from here again.
Pretty mediocre pizza. They burned it the first time through and gave me two new slices, but the pizza was still not too special.

Ordered a large BBQ chicken pizza (BBQ sauce, BBQ chicken and bacon), medium cheese pizza and medium gourmet pizza (vegetarian - artichoke, feta and sundried tomatoes) with a large caesar salad and large spring mix for a group of 9 people.  It was the perfect amount of pizza (we had 3 extra slices of the BBQ pizza) and we could have done with one less salad.  Everyone loved the pizza and they delivered it right on time.   Great experience.  With some soft drinks it cost about $98 before tip.
Tried a slice of the pesto chicken pizza: hearty, flavorful and cheesy.

Dude this has to be one of the best pizza places in SF. I was up there a few times for work and this was my go to spot for a quick bite. I only really ate the cheese or pep. Mainly cheese. They will warm it up for u and u are just ready to go. I was able to make it for happy hour which makes each slice like $2.50 I believe so it was even nicer and they serve beef and always have a game playing! Chill spot to say the least.
Huge thin slices of pizza. Sierra Nevada, corona and Heineken beers in bottles. Anchor, lagunitas and one other beer I forgot on tap

Last month I find out that my temp job assignment was ending (sad face).  I wanted to leave with a happy face and have a happy hour lunch with my then co-workers.  I ordered a huge 'Glorious Chicken' pizza with white sauce plus some buffalo chicken wings.  Fantastic pizza, the chicken wings weren't so bad either, but oh that pizza.  Delivered pretty quickly and it was enough for everyone in the office.  Loved it.

Have been reading posts from ex-NY'ers claiming EFNY pizza is "meh"...they're wrong!  I'm an ex-NY'er (20 yrs in Manhattan/Bklyn) and definitely know my pizza and Escape does it right as far as I'm concerned.  Their dough is terrific..not too thin, not too thick..it folds just right and you don't lose any toppings in the process.  My faves are You Say Potato, Pesto and the Barbeque Chicken.  And considering the levels of pizza found here in SF...EFNY rocks!
I'm from New York. Meh. Maybe for SF it's good pizza. Definitely better than area chains. And it's great they deliver late night to the financial district. It's decent pizza, but not NY standards.

Both times I've recently walked in for the happy hour deal ($2.50 pints and pepperoni slices) they have been pulling out a super fresh pepperoni pizza so I can't comment on cold slices or non-happy hour deals. With that said this place is a pretty phenomenal deal for an after work bite. $2.50 for a pint of Lagunitas IPA is the best deal I've found so far in the FiDi. The slices are pretty gigantic and filling, I usually get two and its plenty for dinner. Make sure to get a punch card, getting a free slice after you purchase 7 means essentially a free slice every 4th visit if you usually get two slices like I do. They have all the usual condiments such as italian seasonings, hot peppers and parmesan on hand, though hot sauce would be a welcome addition. 4 stars because although it's a good deal and tasty i'd feel pretty silly giving a place 5 stars for basic pepperoni pizza.
We got in 15 min before they were going to close on Saturday...at 4:45!!! What the...?! So weird for a place that is supposed to have happy hour from 4PM-6PM to close at 5 on a Saturday.

Get FIGGY with it!! Seriously, try the MISS FIGGY PIZZA. Smoked bacon, caramelized figs, fresh arugula, and goat cheese topped with a balsamic glaze...what's not to love? I am a huge fan of the sweet and tangy flavor of this particular pizza.

They serve some hearty thin crust pizza which are good for the heart metaphorically but probably not too good for the heart literally. No pizza is but we love it right. Everything in moderation and you will be fine.
The pizza itself is amazing.
I appreciate the quick delivery, friendly delivery guy & qty of pizza for the money. However, pizza was just ok for me.
Good pizza. Has a great flavor in the sauce and lots of cheese.
Awesome Pizza!! Buffalo Chicken is my favorite choice.

It's hard to eat on the cheap out in the financial district especially if your a student. This place is what helps is beauty school students. Great pizza and so many to choose from. My friend always gets the you say potato and I love the mushroom since I'm a mushroom oholic. 3-4 a slice is nice! These slices aren't small at all! Big in fact so you get a huge bang for your buck!!

Wanted to try something other than North Beach Pizza.  Googled and EFNYP came up.  Read the reviews.  "You Say Potato" pizza got rave reviews so I had to try it.  I love pizza, I love pesto and I love potatoes so how can you go wrong with a potato pizza!  I did pull off the chunks of garlic though.  YUMMY!
It's not as good as most New York style pizza, but it's pretty good.  You really can't find the great NY pizza in San Francisco.

Escape from NY Pizza is my favorite pizza in SF, hands down. I practically lived off their pesto pizza during a stint of vegetarianism in my college days! This location is close to where I stay when visiting SF so I usually hit it up at least once. In addition to the pesto, I am partial to the You Say Potato - sliced potato and garlic on pizza is genius. Bonus star for $2 beers during happy hour.  You know you want to have a couple of Anchor Steams with that :)
My company has brought in pizza from here on numerous occasions. They have a great variety to satisfy any taste.  And. It. Is. Goooood!

Burnt the hell out of my tongue, but the pizza was good. Nothing amazing pizza-wise, but at the price it's exactly what you paid for. Definitely one of the cheapest options I've found downtown so far!
Pizza was stale and worse off. Overcooked, you could taste that the sauce was old as it had that "off" flavor to it

My co-workers were ranting and raving about the bagels at this place.  Decided to try it last week - they were sold out of bagels at 9:30 a.m.  - ok maybe that's a good sign I said. Tried it again today. Got a bagel. NOT IMPRESSED. The bagel is the size of an English muffin, if that. Hard as a rock because it was toasted too long and it's too thin. Super expensive for what you get.  They can keep it. I'll go to the deli down the street.
Delicious and fulfilling food...BUT EXPENSIVE!  Should at least try a Rachel...or their tasty egg sandwich!  Perhaps visit quarterly or semiannually....

Matzoh Brie here was great. I've never ordered that in a restaurant before and wasn't sure how it would come out. The fresh fruit was a nice touch, though not reflective of tradition in my house--I'm no stickler! I loved it.

I am from out of town and was working nearby.  I went there for breakfast and had the challah french toast -- it was tasty.  It was nice and hot, and came with a heaping helping of syrup and butter.  It also had apples and pears on top.
The two stars are for the edible corned beef.  Although it's pretty dry.  The 3 empty stars are based on the following comments:
I try so hard not to dole out the one star rating for food but I couldn't even finish my meal without wanting to write this review.

I'm going to start this review by praising their exceptional client service. My sweet Patricija P. is not a rye lover, and in a moment of panic after she ordered the special grilled cheese and we were admiring the salt and pepper vessel, she asked one of the line chefs about the bread. There is no alternative to rye, so if you can't stomach the fennel seeds, be aware. And what was their solution? There was no hesitation on their part, they switched out her grilled cheese sandwich for a plate of the most delicious latkes with creme fraiche and apple sauce ($7).

Paying $14 for a sandwich is never going to rub me the right way.  You see the # on the menu, you think about the insanity, then you pay.  Then you wait.  Lastly, you bite into the most perfect rye bread and then sink your teeth into the best pastrami you've had in years!  This is seriously one of the best sandwiches in the city.  It's just pastrami on rye, and it's thick cut, smokey, salty perfection.  This is a great sandwich, you're paying for the love of the craft of house cured meats.
Just had lunch there with a friend. Very good and fairly lean pastrami and corned beef. Sides (potato knish and kugel) were fine, but nothing special. Pleasant service.

Perhaps I picked the wrong item .. .Salmon Croquettes were the lunch special today which I ordered  "to-go".  When I returned to work and anxiously opened the box, I found two very orange colored lumps of macerated salmon-flavored fish cakes ... NOT croquettes at all.  Similar to a "Salmon Cake" but definitely not croquettes by their very definition. In a city full of foodies, you can't get away with calling something a croquette when it is so far from it!  I took one bite and had to spit it out as the taste was horrible.  I can't afford to waste $9.95 so my cat will get quite a treat for dinner tonight.  Do not .... I repeat ... do not ever, ever order croquettes here or you will be more than disappointed.  Blech!

Got my sandwich to go -- mustard that is mentioned was on the tables but not on my beef liver sandwich.   So that could be part of the solution.... but, have to say that I was really surprised that the liver sandwich was so sweet - and the grain of the liver so fine that it was like a dessert pudding sandwich.   blargh.    I was expecting something more savory and think that's kind of the usual so wanted to warn folks.   (I could be wrong... )

LOVED the Rachel sandwich. The pastrami melted in my mouth. Totally worth the price given the high quality, huge size, and SF location. The Knishes were delicious too. Little pillows of potato goodness. Will definitely be back.

Based on my LOVE of his pastrami, I reached out to Michael Siegel -owner and head chef at Shorty's- to see if his team could accommodate a dinner for my team at Oracle. He came back with a perfect menu suggestion within our budget and rearranged the tables at the venue for our group of about 20 people.
4 Stars for food + ambiance, -1 for dat price.
Great food and brilliant service. This place is right below my office and when I need to slide out and grab something this is my first port of call.
Amazing Pastrami sandwich! It can get crowded during lunch time but the amazing flavors of the sandwiches make up for the wait.

Located right across the street from the old office, Shorty Goldstein's is a Jewish Deli, only much hipper than any Jewish Deli I've ever been to.  Also, no one yells at you here, like they do at the ones in New York.  So that's a bonus.

I ordered the corned beef Benedict! Let just say the food was good but the price was very expensive! This is a place I would visit every 3 months! $14 bucks for eggs Benedict is very expensive for a big time Eggs Benedict fan!
Delicious brisket sandwich on toasted rye with bagel chips.  Love it.  Service was good as well.
My company catered from here and the food was unbelievable bad.
Pretty solid lunch spot!  I ordered the Market Salad, which they change seasonally.  The salad was great, and the fresh mozzarella tasted perfect with the juicy heirloom tomatoes.
Best corned beef I've ever had in California. Nuff said.
Such good smells wafting from this tiny window. J got the veggie soup, rife with heirloom tomatoes and creaminess. Adding the farmer's market salad with its fresh pulled mozzarella sealed the deal.

ehh.  I spent a little over $21 for two sandwiches. We had the beef tongue and beef salami.   I didn't enjoy it as much because the mustard was spicy and the smell of pickles killed it for me.  I did, however, pick apart the sandwich and had the beef tongue on its own.  It was delicious.
Just the worst bagel ever. Too dry, and it took eleven minutes to bring it out. Schmear on the side. Thanks guys, if I wanted to construct my own bagel, I wouldn't pay you $5 to do it for me.

I really wanted to like this place. I've been there twice now and it's just not worth it.  I had the pastrami breakfast bagel and was sorely disappointed.  Wasn't expecting the pastrami to be mixed in with the egg.  Thought it would come as a slice.  For the price it's definitely not worth it.  There are better places to get a breakfast sandwich!  I haven't had lunch there but don't think I will.  Also bought a jar of the pickle but it's bland.  Skip it!
The latkas are FANTASTIC - some of the best I've ever had.  As many have said, the pastrami sando was a little disappointing - sliced too thick, too fatty and small for the price.
Good deli in FiDi. It's not in the same league as New York's delis but for a quick lunchtime option, it's great.

Holy Hannah, the latkes are amazing. The apple chutney served with them makes it. I grabbed some to go while I was in the city. Amazingly, they made it back to Sactown without getting gross. I threw them in the oven for a few and they were perfect.
Why do I keep getting pulled in by these hipster joints? Overpriced food, served shabby-- sheik style.
Good pastrami, good coleslaw - but the bread slices were smaller than wonderbread - seriously, make me a sandwich I can hold - especially for the price - I think you can get bigger bread.

at $14, its an expensive sandwich that takes a long time to make and a caloric one too but despite all this, the Rachel - the pastrami sandwich with cole slaw and swiss is now my favorite pastrami sandwich.   Pastrami is delicious!!!

If you read the other reviews about this place - the complaints are 1) price and 2) a Jewish guy from the East Coast rating West Coast deli  -  come on...we aren't comparing apples to apples. Everyone knows deli is BEST on the EC.  BUT as far as San Francisco goes for pastrami/corned beef - this place ROCKS. I prefer a Dill-ier pickle but to each his own. Price wise - yes, it's on the pricey side, but so is F'ing San Francisco! I LOVE this place. I go every chance I get. Then I go for a walk!
Some of the staff is pretty snotty and I just paid $14 for a mediocre salad with NO dressing.  So pretentious.

Nice decor, good vibes and service, but it's pretty damn expensive! It's even more than Wise Sons. It ends up around $15 for a pastrami sandwich including tax. It was tasty and good-quality ingredients but just a bit to pricy for what it is. Nice to see more Jewish delis around SF though.
I have tried this cool place several times now.  And every time I eat their food I always say: " Boy, I love these flavors"!

There I was, walking down Sutter St., when I saw Shorty Goldstein's.  Could it be?  A Jewish-ish deli type place?  I ventured to the front to look at the menu.  Not only was it true, but they had potato knish!!!!!  Outside of Saul's in Berkeley, I can't find a potato knish anywhere.

Craving a big corned beef and swiss sandwich, I walked over to Shorty Goldstein's today for lunch. My craving for coned beef was so severe, that I ordered a pastrami sandwich, to which I added swiss. I would've loved to try some of the other menu items, but the $15 price tag on my sandwich persuaded me to skip the sides. The fresh rye bread was good but a tad on the doughy side. The meat was memorable, good smoky, salty pastrami. The pickles were fine. The mustard on the table was great. But I was left wanting simply because I paid $15 for a sandwich at quick service restaurant. SG's is a good spot if you're craving jewish vittles, but it's better if some one else is paying for lunch.

Tried their beef tongue sandwich today.   I was pleasantly surprised, not at beef tongue itself, but how they prepared the sandwich.  There was a sweet and pickled jam/vegetable on top of the meat, and it really brought out the flavor of the meat.  Bread is everything and I wasn't disappointed by the bread.  Potato salad could be a little less spicy but I appreciated the consistency of it. Lemonade was really sweet but you could tell it's not that fake stuff.  Entire meal was $12 with tax.  Not bad for a casual lunch with the girlfriend.
Amazing taste, fresh and friendly!

Stopped in for a drink prior to going up to my room at the hotel next door. Ordered their jalapeno ginger margarita- tasted good spicy like I like it. However, only intending to have one drink went to cash out and apparently they only accept debit cards for purchases above $20! That is ridiculous!  Its not like I'm buying a $2 soft drink its a $10 + tax cocktail! That is just obnoxious and cheap. I asked if they had a debit charge and, no, only the $20 min. Just silly!! Thanks now I can get screwed by both your "convenient" ATM fees and my banks fee.Jesus it's 2014 get SQUARE.

Rounding up from my real rating of 3.5 stars. I hosted a private event here, and it's a perfect place for a small VIP party if you are looking for a venue. The main event space is gorgeous, with small booths and a good sized dancefloor area where we had a table for hors d'oeuvres.
Two stars because they automatically add gratuity to your bill even though your party is less than 6.  Look and ask for  the itemized receipt..

Do not give these people your credit card.  They will overcharge you (apparently the menu price is not the real price) and charge you for things you did not order.  Went here with some friends, didn't order food, but was billed for food and they were completely arrogant about the mistake even though they had continually brought orders to our table that were not ours.  Extremely rude staff who basically steal from first time guests as they count on you not living in SF to come back and contest the charges.  Never going back.

Ok no fronts...I'm drunk as hell right now. Just came from Region where the baby octopus was good, bun bo hue was "aite" and the service was so so when it came to getting your order right. But it's Thursday, I got drunk there, I sang, rapped, drank, danced with other drunk hotties and made new friends. Granted I'm pretty awesome but it's a great place to meet other awesome people through karaoke and alcohol. Went here on a lark and will def be back. I can see how a place like this can have an off day. All I can say is I had the raddest Thurs night in a long time. Ok back to my drunken Bart ride....
I really enjoyed the attention to detail that this restaurant pays to both the food and the decor. Finally a trendy bar in the city that has good food too!

Came with a coworker after work....well break from work, since I had to hit the laptop later that night, and need a good HH fix. Thought I would try this place out, as it was on my happy hour (HH) list, and near my office in the Fidi.

Went here for dinner and choose all seafood options: Pad Thai prawns, salt and pepper squid, papaya salad with calamari, and salmon. It all sounded really good but we were pretty darn disappointed. All the seafood was obviously frozen and reheated. Nothing tasted remotely fresh or flavorful. Prices are steep for the lower quality and bland food. Seemed like other people were there for the happy hour. Maybe the drinks are worth it? We left with our stomachs full of food but still hungry for taste. FYI there is also a $20 min for credit cards and an automatic 18% gratuity included in the bill.

The second time I came here was two weeks ago for karaoke, I thought the sound system wasn't good (it was probably belonged to the owner) and didn't like the energy. However, I went on 8-21-14 8:40pm'sh, this time my friends and I ordered fried egg rolls, soup that contained ham and noodles, few other items, definitely delicious. I drank two trumers beers, amf, and a mojito.  Also, they repositioned their speakers and the karaoke machine more towards the front of the bar, much better sound, and more persons entered into this venue.  My friends and I sang at least 3 songs and was enjoyable to hang around with them.

My most recent trip to SF was to see Beyonce and JayZ in concert at AT&T park. My cousin and I were to meet friends for happy hour prior to the concert they decided on Region because of its central location. Upon entry I was met with delightful aromas and sounds of laughter and numerous conversation. The diningroom is a lofty comfortable space appropriately decorated with contemporary furniture and lighting. The happy Hour Menu was quite extensive and diverse in its offerings. To start I ordered the Japanese tea cocktail. The drink wasn't a standout in my opinion and tasted almost exactly like a midori sour. Our small plates were next, spareribs (they were actually full pork ribs) , 8 spice chicken , stuffed peppers and a mushroom steamed rice. The ribs were by far my favorite, the tender meat literally slipped off the bone and into my mouth sending me into heavenly bliss with each bite.  The other items were good and quite filling, our table. Myself and others included absolutely enjoyed ourselves. For a happy hour spot in such close proximity to the concert venue I expected them to be better staffed. Our server was also the bartender and with such a lean staff he was pulled in several different directions and service suffered as a result. I will definitely return for dinner and to try other small plate offerings. Region is a great place for food and for friends to have fun!
udon beef soup is good. and pork shanks

Had dinner reservations at Region for dinner and was curious about the food there since I've heard about the place being a lounge nightclub in the evenings.  The bar area is in the front and the spacious dining room had three booths in one side and larger booth table on the other sides and some tables in the middle of the room with a DJ booth overlooking the floor.  You can see how this is set up to be a nightlclub with the dance floor in the middle.
Doris and Matthew the bartender are the best.  Great service, good drinks, cool place.
Pretty standard fare - decent food while you pay for the 'trendy' atmosphere.  Also seems to be a spot where you can rent out the place post-dinner, if you're having a private party or something.

If you are in town on business this is a pretty good option if you are alone. The food is decent, drinks solid and service acceptable. You will certainly not be blown away by your experience and your expense account will take a hit but there are not too many places in San Francisco that will not kill the expense account.

Hip little joint. Not terribly family-friendly, but someone recommended it to my uncle so off the 16 of us went! For a Saturday night it was dead, which is generally a warning sign, but the club-like atmosphere made it seem like it gets busier later in the evening. I ordered the salmon rolls, the special fries, and the short rib ramen. All of which were tasty and seemed to be freshly-prepared. The waitress seemed a bit frazzled and forgot to take my father's order twice. Most of my brothers and cousins order pho, my husband got pad Thai, and I saw some duck on the table too. No complaints but nothing special. They did accommodate my picky young daughter with some plain pork skewers and a plan prep of the fries that she actually ate, so that was a success.
Living nearby in South Beach it can be hard to find new places to go out for food. This night we didnt want to go to our old haunts and so found this little number on opentable.
Very mediocre food and the wait staff seemed disorganized and not very interested in service. Won't return.
Short Story:
Very mediocre food.  Wait staff is plentiful, but a bit disorganized.  Asked for no jalapeño on my dish only to have it there.  Drinks are relatively good. Music is very loung-y. Nothing special.

We were at Region for a Bday Party, but had dinner prior. We had the BBQ pork ramen, the salmon rolls, and the house fries. Ramen was pretty good. I didn't really like the salmon roll much. And, the fries were okay. Food, I thought, was 3.5 at best. I heard good things about the duck dish and the Pad Thai, but I didn't try them.

There was bad traffic on the bridge and I pulled off and found this place. I remember coming to this spot before when it was a Mexican restaurant, now its some kind of fusion. I ordered a Tiger Beer and some pork sticks during happy hour. It was OK nothing fantastic, but I saw more interesting items on the menu that I would like to try next time.
This place is pretty good. A few of my friends and I went the Wednesday before Valentines day and ordered 4 dishes plus 4 glasses of champagne.

Came here after work to grab a bite. It was packed but were still able to be seated. We expected slow service as it was valentines day. Everything we ordered was on point. Must try : fried baby octopus and house french fries with furikake (seaweed) and truffle oil. The grass fed beef is a bit spicy but delicious (might want to order side of rice next time)
My experience here is similar to the one that Eddie W. wrote about just a short time ago this year.
Happy Hour Review only
Came here to have some good Beijing Duck (Peking Duck) and was not disappointed.  Well prepared with fresh condiments and pancakes. Look for it in the appetizer section.

With Region so close to our office, we decided to give them a try for happy hour. As soon as you walk in, the ambiance is definitely slick and feels like you have been transported to a lounge club in Vegas. It is definitely great for groups and ample seating for such a tight space.

I've never eaten here, only been for drinks. The drinks are decent, not too pricey (though not cheap) and the service is quite good.  The problem is, this smell comes in from the Bay and it smells like rotten eggs/sulfur so strongly it makes you gag.  I've been here probably 6 times (yes, I keep going back as it is across the street from my office) and the smell has happened 4 times.  Fun place other than the smell.
Had crispy rolls and ramen.  The crispy rolls were good. Ramen was weird.  It has bok choy, seaweed, cilantro and green onions.   Not that tasty.   The decor was like a club.
Had friends birthday there, drinks were awesome, specially the Asian bartender made his own special drinks!!
I have been here several times spread out over many months, maybe over a year. The food is good but the service is really poor.

Came here for a company party. Ambiance and food was ok. The frame in the front that looks like a fireplace is cool. I didn't like I had to leave the building and go outside to use the bathroom. The bar tenders were nice and did a great job pouring drinks. They have a dj booth that is elevated, kinda cool location, but the sound system could be better.

The reservation system is poorly attended.  Made a web reservation 3 days ahead - no response.  Call requesting confirmation c/b morning of planned meal, no c/b.  Stop in 90' ahead and advised there's a private party.  Little apparent concern and no responsible employee available to provide feedback.
I work across the street and have been to Region several times and unfortunately, have been nothing but disappointed.
We ordered two drinks (a whiskey and a gin on the rocks) and the bartender screwed them both up. This place is awful. We will never be back.
My wife and I love this place. The half or whole duck is great. Region has a rad atmosphere, too. Worth checking out.

This review is only for the bar area. We were staying in The Griffon Hotel next door and stopped by for happy hour drinks because the lighting in the bar area was very inviting. We were seated promptly, but then it was very difficult to get the attention of our server after that. It was apparent that the servers were more interested in chatting with each other rather than serving us. I'm only going with the two stars because the bar has a good physical aura, although the ATM machine by the front door is tacky. The cheap drinks and tasty potstickers partially make up for the in attentive servers. Perry's in the hotel a few steps away is a better choice.

The food may be great, but the service is horrific. Went there last night, and there were only about 6 tables seated. They have ONE waitress for the whole dining room taking order, serving drinks, and bussing tables. After 20 minutes of ordering our first drinks we are told they are out of Tiger beer. I order a Trumer. She brings a Stella after another 5 minute wait, saying they are out of Trumer. At the 45 minute mark we had accomplished only one drink each, and the appetizers showed up at the 45 minute mark. Now we order a second round of drinks. Seriously, it took 20 minutes for the second round to show up. Asked for waters as well - those NEVER showed up. The service was ridiculously SLOW and the waitress became rude halfway into the dinner because I asked her how long it will take to get water. My suggestion: Stay Away From This poorly run business. It won't be long before there is a "For Lease" sign in the window.
Amazing service in the heart of Embarcadero's restaurant district! Great drinks and Happy Hour! Great management and atmosphere make Region a great meet-up place for anyone to enjoy.
service was great! food was good and i will coming back.

Good sushi and convenient location for after dinner activities. Great date night spot. Reservations are pretty easy to get. Got the spicy tuna, spicy salmon, spicy crunch roll, and volcano roll. Volcano roll was our favorite. Prices are pretty average for a sushi place in the city.

I have eaten here many times but have yet to rate until now and for a Japanese fix, we come here because this seems to be the only place in the Downtown area where it is convenient, near BART.  This restaurant is located in the newly remodeled Metreon, which now has an expanded food court besides this restaurant inside the mall.  When we came, it was bustling with office workers and people attending a convention.  We ordered the chicken teriyaki, salmon teriyaki and Bento Box special of the day!  The daily bento box special is totally worth it for the price and it was fried oysters, with gyoza, California roll, fruit, salad and soup!  All were good except that I made the mistake of ordering chicken teriyaki which was grilled and alittle dry.
It's a-ok. It's fairly expensive and the food is fairly mediocre. There are many better options in the city.

I give it 1 star because of their business practice.  I never ordered out...always eaten in.  On their menu, an entree comes with salad, rice and soup.  Well guess what...you don't get soup if you take out.  Really...poor business practice and cheap.
Went with a large group and got the large boat. Sushi was good.  Rolls about what you would expect and nigiri delicious. Located inside a mall or something but not bad.
Great staff, great food, amazing place! I come to this place at least once in a week. It's one of my favorite spots in the city!

Had dinner here while I was up in SF for a conference. We were seated immediately and our server was very friendly. Menu selection was fairly typical with standard American Japanese options and a few specialty rolls that sounded good. There were also several vegetarian options, which was nice as one person in our party was vegetarian.

got to try the sashimi salad that seems to be rather popular. I want to give this place a 3.5 but overall it was good but for $15, it wasn't worth it I think. You get a variety of fishes such as salmon, tuna, and white tuna and some roe. The salad is green mix and then a few tomatoes as well so it wasn't anything super fancy. I could have gotten a whole chirashi sample and a lot more for that price at another location. Fish was fresh though and didn't taste slimey or anything.

Great food and service (thank you, Haruna) with outdoor dining on a beautiful day in San Francisco - what more can you ask for.  Had the bento box for lunch. Everything looked and tasted fresh, the delicate flavors well balanced. The miso soup was not too salty as it typically is at other Japanese restaurants. The fried mackerel was perfectly crisp and the chicken teriyaki was just right. And bonus points for refilling my drink before running out..

Who would think a restaurant attached to a  shopping mall would have great service and 4 star food? I sure didn't, but I'm glad we stopped here after the Giant's game. The restaurant was busy, but the staff was VERY attentive which made all the difference. When we received our food, we were pleased with its quality and taste. I'd recommend this place again.

I go here for lunch often and always get the Chirashi. It has ikura and uni on it, which can't always expect in other sushi places. It's fresh and gorgeous. I usually have to get a hamachi roll to get really full though!
In San Fran for a business trip. Came here with a co-worker based upon Yelp reviews. We thought we'd give it a shot since it was close to our hotel and the fact we were hungry for sushi.

Impressive for a busy Friday night dinner. As soon as my husband and I sat down we were ready to order. The waitress was prompt and attentive. As soon as we put in our orders she asked us if we were in a hurry. Bonus points for that! We were in no hurry but it's an important question to ask when in the city. I think that was the first time any waitress has asked me that! I ordered the sesame chicken - crispy & sweet, a tad over cooked (meat was slightly dry but barely noticeable). My husband ordered the garlic rib eye steak. It came out on a sizzling platter - pretty standard, soft meat (a plus!), a tad bland so we added soy sauce. Good food, not sure the price reflects but, hey, we're in the city!
Ordered the Sushi Deluxe Platter. Fresh and delicious. A LOT of food for a very reasonable price.
Most accommodating servers. Food was good but the rolls all started tasting the same. Rolls are 6 pieces so keep that in mind when sharing.
This is our regular haunt. Great food, great service. And Chef Shinji is THE BEST!

This is our go-to spot for sushi night. It's priced right and close to the action, located in the Metreon, with a nice dining area. I would give it five stars, but sometimes the service is a little hit-or-miss. I've had fabulous servers with great recommendations and table service, and some that forget orders and never come back to the table.
The best sushi. Saporo is always great and chilled. Don't miss the Kinmedai and O Toro nigiri sushi

Food is ok, but nothing like being rushed through a meal. Entree arrived a few minutes after the soup and salad. My daughters food arrived 10 minutes later. Not good timing. Then you notice a trend. You know when you get that feeling when the staff really wants to turn over your table really fast. As soon as my glass of beer was empty,  it was swept away along with our napkins. Not even an offer for a refill.
This restaurant is inside the METREON in the food court, but the ambiance is nice enough.
First time trying this place out. I really liked how their sushi roll was prepared. The rice was perfectly cooked and the proportions were plenty for me (glad to not over eat).
Excellent rock-and-roll.  Waitress is kind and efficient, very good at her job while seeming humble.  I got free edamame since I have movie tickets.  Good tea.
Nabeyaki udon is a must try.
I had two rolls to go. I liked it because they don't pack rice like some places do. The sashimi was fresh.
Quality of the tuna is questionable. Bone in the imitation crab they put into the dragon roll.  Tempura heavy, greasy, and salty.
It has slipped.

It was alright. Definitely good for a "mall" restaurant but the service was sketchy and slow, and our food came at different times - actually, I had to ask where mine was. JJ had the teriyaki which was really good and lots of it, but he was practically finished by the time my sushi arrived despite eating really slowly. I had the spider roll, the hamachi and the bonito. Loved the spider roll, but felt that the hamachi wasn't kickin' fresh but the bonito was good. Wouldn't go back unless I went with others.
Sushi was good enough.  Fish was fresh.  Given their location, I'm surprised they don't step it up a notch.  Service was lackluster.
Better than typical food-court fare, Sanraku is consistently decent. An elegant pre-movie meal that will leave you feeling nourished.
I never knew I was eating second-rate fish elsewhere 'til I tried the Sashimi Lunch and tasted how fresh the fish is here!

Food was pretty good, but service was definitely lacking.  Had the sashimi salad - lots of fresh fish atop greens.  Dressing was good, but was kind of odd trying to make it spicy with bits of wasabi rather than hot sauce/spicy dressing.  Waiter never stopped by to ask about the food - not even when we dropped off the check.  And they tried charging for the seaweed salad that I ordered but was never delivered.

Great location right next to the Moscone convention center. Next to the gardens with indoor and outdoor seating. Great sushi menu with decently priced lunch specials. The service is pretty quick for a sushi bar too.
Review of an average tuesday night:

Very rude. I called for a to-go order and they put me on hold for 10 mins. I called back saying I was on hold for 10 mins, all she said was "We're really busy". She didn't even apologize or even try to take my order. I asked if I can order food to-go and she said "you have to hold for a few mins"... This is the worst service I've received in my life. I'm never ever going there. I hate restaurants that treat their customers like dirt!!
I really liked the food here.  Its busy during lunch hour.
This sushi restaurant is located in the Yerba Buena shopping center. I came here after work with a friend and thought the food was really good. We ordered the following:

Wasn't that impressed with the food. We came because we watched a movie earlier and if you present your movie ticket, you get free edamame and a free Sapporo beer. I ordered the miso clam soup and it was a bit salty and there was some sand. The miso grilled fish (similar to misoyaki) was really water and had no miso. The garlic chicken came on a grilled plate which looked nice, but really didn't have flavor. The service here is good though.
I liked the food and the patio was awesome!
Friday night - we made a reservation through the yelp app and got seated right away. The staff was really friendly.
Went here for a private party last night... was my first time attending though I had heard a lot about it.

I was a guest of 3 members at this Club.  Truly a treat for experiencing a classic, place. I wasn't impressed by the menu or the decor, but you knew you were somewhere nice, where people that make the world turn have a meal while enjoying privacy, and conducting business. It reminded me of the city club but much much nicer. tony is phenomenal!

I love Villa Taverna! My boyfriend's parents are long-time members of the club, and I am lucky enough to be able to go and eat here. I was last here for Rich Aurelia's private wine tasting and dinner which of course was amazing.
I was the tag along and got a chance to eat here.  The food was amazing and as you would expect at a private diner club the service was top notch.  Hope I will have a chance to come back again.

This place is pretty amazing - if you get a chance to eat here, definitely don't pass it up. As another yelper mentioned, the exclusivity of this private dining club definitely lends some street cred. The front door is discreetly located in the alley that runs along Aventine and once you enter the first door, you're greeted by a second set of heavy doors reading "members only". The food and service were amazing. Definitely the best caesar salad I've ever eaten - the dressing and croutons tasting like they had a hint of truffle. I was lucky enough to eat dinner hear as part of a wedding rehearsal dinner, would love another opportunity at some point!

I used to take Villa Taverna for granted but as I get older, I realize that this is part of the old school charm that is disappearing.  Jeremy and Tony are really great and the food has gotten better. If you want something casual, the back room is good for jeans and no tie.  No exceptions are made for the front room.  But that's what makes this place retro-cool.  Plus I have learned that my out of town visitors enjoy going to a private dining club and running into big time Washington politicians.  It adds to my, how shall I put this---street cred????

I have never wanted to belong to a private club before. It's really not my style. Except perhaps the PYC but that's for a different review.  The Villa Taverna has a distinct charm about it that changed my mind. I want to belong here.

Apparently the life-long chef has passed away and they have done some real updates to the menu. It's now seasonal, several choices. There is a new events guy (Jeremy) who is very accommodating and took care of most of the planning. We had lamb or halibut. The lamb was delicious and others were very pleased with the fish. The staff is just super-nice, and Tony is STILL there!
Went here for an event tonight for Vernon Jordan. The Villa was quite cool. The staff friendly and quite cordial. The decor and paintings reminds me of 16th century..

I'm sort of up in the air about Villa Taverna. First off, it's a private club, and the memberships are quite pricey. The place itself is quite small, with a couple of dining rooms - sort of a maze effect. The decor was nothing special, just very simple and well done - great linens, heavy silver and crystal - that sort of thing, which I happen to like!

This place is really bizarre. People are old-fashioned polite (I swear two senators wished me good afternoon in the lobby), service is like you're at your rich grandpa's house (Jeeves with an Italian accent - let's say Jeevio - serves you) (was that offensive?) (or just really dumb?), and you pay on account (i.e. no bill at the end of the meal). My canneloni was superb. The creme brulee, though, was terrible. It wasn't fresh, as evidenced by the globbiness beneath the cracked shell.
Had dinner here last night.  It was a retirement party for a friend.

Don't get the salad and sandwich lunch combo. The salad was just tossed in the box and the sandwich right on top of it. I felt like I was eating out of the garbage. The salad was just regular mixed greens and I wasn't too sure it was the freshest. I can't speak for the rest of the food but I was not happy with my lunch combo....
While on the hunt for some healthier, whole food type sustenance we stumbled upon The Plant and it was pretty good.

I don't know why I keep going back.  Well, I do...the food is good no doubt about it.  But as I sit here today eating my $12 dino kale and quinoa salad, I'm just mad.  Already, $12 is a lot for a pile of kale, but at least it has other additions, right?  Not really.  Cherry tomatoes - I counted 5 half cherry tomatoes.  Quinoa - I have taken to ordering (and paying for) extra just to get more than a tablespoon amount.  Lastly, cucumber - 4 half moon slices.  This is just ridiculous and more of a joke than anything.  The people in my office laugh at me for continuing to go here when they see the measly little salad that I come back with.  It's healthy, convenient, and fresh, but you certainly don't get what you pay for.  Mixt Greens and Tender Greens are way better local options for the money.  And until people stop buying in to the madness of Plant, myself included, it will never change.
Good vegan options, average service, with a nice ambience. Waterfront seating is a welcome accompaniment to any brunch.

This is a great place to meet friends for lunch downtown if half your friends are vegetarian/vegan and the rest are carnies.  They don't take reservations like the Embarcadero location so if you're hoping to beat the lunch rush, grab a table by 11:30 a.m. and you're good!

I'd give the Plant a 3.5 if I could.  The plant is a great place to eat if you are trying to be healthy.  The food is usually fresh, the smoothies are pretty good and their salads are tasty.  For me though, the problem is just that some items (like salads) expensive and the lines are super long at lunchtime.  It just seems odd to get a salad and a drink and still spend over $20.  It's not that it's TOO expensive, just never seems like a good value.
Love Blue Bottle Coffee!!

Was on my way to a meeting, and seriously what is better for breakfast than blue bottle coffee and a freshly made smoothie?  Best part, the smoothies are either diary free or can be made that way.  I am in love.  Just wish they were located in my work hood.

On the fence with this place- to start I'll say positives: it's delicious and they accommodate orders face to face or over the phone. They offer delivery and give or take 10min on the time are very reliable. But... Despite how delicious the Dino kale salad is, I've found bugs in the salad on more than one occasion. Ok ok I know, kale is curly and hard to wash- but wash it more thoroughly, if I wanted more protein I would have asked for chicken. Also just adding salmon to anything is $10 - kinda steep. I won't stop ordering from this place, but just be a little eye careful as you pick through your salad next time.

Would go back only because I care what I eat, most of the time. Service was good, ambiance was kinda industrial/modern ( a bit lacking) and fish taco's were pretty good... Not explosive or memorable though; a side of fresh peppers might have done the trick ;D Nevertheless, the only reason I would go back would be because it's organic one, and two, hoping to find  more flavour in some of the other items.
This place is organic alright!

Yeah, sort of not really impressed by The Plant. My coworker had ordered the tuna campagna sandwich and was eating it in his cubicle and it looked really good, so I decided I'd make the trip downstairs and around the corner from us to try it myself.

I really do love the food here, but ordering food is such a hassle. We ordered to our office, but the online ordering system does not allow you to note any food allergy. So when I called, they then asked me to email my order and they seem a bit offended if you call to place an order. Not sure what the deal with that is! Four stars for the food--not service!
Had a horrible experience here.  This place is over-priced and was a complete disappointment.
Yeah it gets busy.

Kind of the go-to place for my firm for lunch.  If it wasn't so expensive maybe I'd go there more often, but I just can't justify the prices - unless someone else is paying!  I do enjoy their lunches - the fish taco, quinoa and veggie dish, ginger iced tea - all delicious.  However, $4 for ice tea?  $9.75 for a smoothie with almond milk?  Uh-uh.
Great salads, all organic ingredients. A great selection of smoothies  and juices and blue bottle coffee!
Insanely overpriced baked goods and smoothies.

So I know that working in downtown means my meals will be spend-y compared to other areas but I've accepted that fact. What I find unacceptable is if I've paid over ten bucks for a tortilla wrap and some sliced fruit.

If you're vegan (and there's nothing wrong with that, more plant power to you), this place has great options. I know lots of people love this place, but I was underwhelmed. Pros: not that packed at 8:30am. Cons: pretty overpriced for a watery energizer fresh juice, and a lukewarm bagel. The veggies served were better than the bagel. It's on the smaller side so I totally understand the other reviews that talk about the endless wait.
Healthy

The was the very first Plant Cafe that I ever visited.  My main reason for visiting was my curiosity to try their famous Plant Burger.  I was a bit skeptical because it's a veggie burger, but I've heard so many good things about it, even from the meat-eaters.
These guys just get it right. All their locations are consistently good - make that excellent.
Used to be a fan of their smoothies and get the "Green" three times a week. I dont know if they changed the recipe or what but for the last couple of times, it was all watery,..

I definitely like this place. The variety is awesome, the food it good, the vibe is cool...but it's ALWAYS packed and seating is near impossible. I had the green thai bowl and it was bomb. Will have to try more!
The "I Like You" Haiku

So-so. The salads are ok. Banana bread is consistently good. Breakfast burrito is sort of pitiful. Smoothies are good. Chicken avocado sandwich is also pretty decent and moist (unlike the chicken they add on to the salads, which is shockingly bland).

This (was) a new favorite. I love the chicken green thai. The veggies are different than I've had ever in this type of dish and definitely fresh. It included chard and maybe pea shoots on top? I also love the fresh juice which is definitely pretty pricey. Overall just an incredible experience. I haven't had any service issues but I also show up after the lunch rush around 2pm.
