I wonder if they expect to see people returning after these actions. By the way, does the gm think that the world cup lasts 6 months? Do not be stupid, the world cup ends in a week! When this happens you will be begging people to go to your restaurant to fill the empty tables!

We just organized a large event at Jillian's. Great communications and planning with the Director of Special Events, Jennifer. She is awesome, super friendly and Fast responses. GM, other managers and staff were really ON it, very Warm welcoming. Great event, great times!!
Cold pizza and warm beer are the best you'll get at Jillian's. Of course, the price you pay is the same you would be paying at Pizza Delfina for quality pizza! Please avoid and go somewhere else!

Went here to watch the last USA World Cup game...great atmosphere, good TV's/screens, drink specials weren't bad but the food was just ok. We ended up waiting a while for it, and when it finally came, it was cold and I'd say average.

Threw a large event there, and it wasnt easy. They didnt know how to work their own PA, nor their projectors. They sold me the use of HDMI, and then said they couldnt do it day of.  The manager was extremely rude to me.   In the end, we had a major blow to the event due to their misleading event documentation.
They charge $10 for watching a game between Brazil and Colombia because, according to the door girl, it gets too crazy.  Yet 0 for the Germany vs France game #racialprofiling #racists
10 minutes at the empty bar, made eye contact with the bartender 3 times and nothing. Had to literally wave them down, which is a pet peeve of mine and bartenders alike

The worst waitress ever!!! Came to watch germany Portugal game. I waited to ask her if my wife and I could have an extra chair so that we could both sit at the bar. After a few moments she turned and yelled at me to go behind the line without answering my question. Unnecessarily rude!

Came here for my first time with my coworkers. Had a really bad experience. My coworkers wanted to watch the world cup and this place had it on tv and close to work. My group had ordered food n drinks but I wasn't hungry. I had said to the waitress that I was good for now. Then got told that I had to order food if I wanted to stay! Wtf. So rude and unnecessary! Food wasn't good and overpriced! Do not recommend.

Worst service ever and The manager very unpolite. We came in a group to watch Brazil's world cup game and all of us ate and drunk. A friend of ours joined us a bit later and didn't feel like eating however the waitress pointed out that she had to eat if she wanted to stat there... She said "Thanks but I will not eat for now" and right after the manager shows up saying we should leave. Very rude and disrespectful. The food not good as well. The salmon salad was way too grease and salmon almost raw. Very bad experience and do nor recommend at all

Not sure why this place is bad. It actually fills a niche - a kid-friendly sports bar in downtown. I looked and looked and this was it. Food wasn't bad. Overall, not bad. This place was clean and spacious and easy.

I've been to this restaurant twice, the first time for our family friend's daughter's 12th birthday when I was 10 and then the second time two months later when we were going out with another family friend of ours for sightseeing when they were visiting us from New Jersey. I always liked the Disco Mac and Cheese when I was a kid and I also love the paintings in there because they look and even happen to be funky as it gets. Next time I come back there, I could try something else (an adult menu, though). Yes, it may be pricey, but it's worth it.

i ordered spinach &cranberries salad. i asked for romaine lettuce instead of spinach and no red onions but i got spinach and red onions. salad was not tossed either... i wont be coming back here for salads.

I've started eating the food I actually buy for breakfast at home, but venue was my go-to for breakfast for a good run since they share a block with our office. Their breakfast burritos are addicting, their smoothies are freshly made, and their staff is so great in the morning. I've found the lunches that I've tried (Caesar salad, pasta, pesto sandwich) to be just okay, but I would definitely recommend them for breakfast

Ordered a chorizo fajita off the menu, was told it didn't exist and that they only had steak fajitas, pointed to the menu where it said Chorizo or Steak fajita, got a uninterested shrug in return. Received a bland steak fajita and an average mocha.

excellent, fresh baked goods. clean, efficient. best part is that they use unsweetened soy milk so the cappuccino isn't overly sweet. great place to stop for a relaxed coffee or breakfast before work.

Corner deli shop that I sometimes go to for breakfast.  They don't have sausage, but the chorizo egg sandwich is surprisingly good and has a nice kick to it.  Nothing special, but had to give a quick shoutout to my neighborhood deli.
My new favorite post commute breakfast. Place.  Good coffee, smoothies and friendly staff.

Love this place! It's around the corner from my office and I go at least once a week. Great sandwiches, salads, and juices. Fairly priced. Very nice staff, and they work very efficiently so the line moves quickly.
So, I previously wrote a glowing review for the Montgomery St. location almost 4 years ago (found here:

I woke up this morning and found myself staring glumly at the uninspiring contents of my refrigerator.  I knew I should just make somehing for myself,  that I was on a budget,  etc etc. But I just couldn't myself to cobble together breakfast out of those options.  So,  once landed in the Financial District,  I began to wander in search of something better,  and,  just a few blocks away,  found Cafe Venue,  which,  for 5.25 (4.25 without avocado/sour cream) gave me probably one of the best breakfast burritos I've ever had.  It was spicy,  just the right size,  and made with real avocados and tomatoes sliced right then.  So,  thank you:  both for the food and for the lack of guilt over stretching my budget a bit;  this was worth it.

Expect long lunch lines, but the assembly line service is fast and efficient. I got the half California sandwich and spicy Thai chicken salad the other day. The sandwich was delicious but minuscule, maybe 3" x 3"? The salad, on the other hand was fairly large for what is supposed to be a half portion. I did love the salad. Generous portions of chicken breast, tossed in greens with carrots and a spicy Thai dressing. The half sandwich/half premium salad combo ran about $10 plus I think.
Breakfast burritos are good

Went there for a veggie breakfast burrito, but not impressed. On the small side, and the mix of vegetables didn't really fit well together. No idea how anything else is that they serve (some of the pics look very yummy, but I'll pass on this next time.

Came here with my boss to grab a quick lunch and get some work done in between meetings. The cafe fills up quickly and during the rush hour, there was a line out the door. Good thing the friendly staff is efficient and manages to move that line. I had the Chop Chop salad, which was delicious and under $8! The small was more than enough and the ingredients were fresh. For those who are eating in the restaurant, there is an area with water (it was pineapple-infused when I went, but don't know if they rotate it). Solid casual grab-and-go lunch spot if you find yourself in the area.

I work right near this place and it is consistently good.  Not only is the staff incredibly friendly and accommodating, but the food is always fresh, fast and cheap.  My go-to is a breakfast sandwich with egg, tomato, avocado and maybe a few other veggies or meats.  Simple, well-prepared, and when all is said and done, my breakfast comes in at $6 or less.  I love this place.
Great people working here, food is great - love the smoothies! Highly recommend to everyone.

I generally despise chains, mostly nation-wide ones like PF Chang's, Cheesecake Factory, and the like; however, in San Francisco I find myself curious to try the local chains which often are delicious (Buckhorn - kinda, Chez Maman, Blue Bottle, Philz, PPQ, Perilla...).

Tried the beet salad minus the blue cheese, Only because I'm not a fan of it but love BEETS! The salad was fresh and filling. The box was so full I couldn't even think of finishing it. I had just the right amount to have on the side with my dinner. The beets were plentiful, the lettuce was perfectly dressed. The cucumbers, cherry tomatoes & shredded carrots rounded out the salad. I will definitely be back to try their other menu options.

The steak fajita breakfast burrito was delicious and affordable for the amount and quality. I wish I had tried this place sooner. I will be back to get that again and try this chop chop salad everyone raves about :)

Normally I don't write reviews but I've gotten so fed up with the poor service at this place. Half the time they get my order wrong or forget things. The plus side is that it's cheap, convenient and the food is good when they make it correctly. I just wish I didn't leave there half the time feeling like I didn't get what I paid for...
Decent spot for lunch... I'd say one of the better places in FiDi. Plenty of seating. The soups are pretty good also.
I ordered a double Americano.   The taste of the espresso was good. Nice and bold. It really woke me up.  Cheap and free wifi here.  What a great place to get some things done and enjoy my Americano.
Came here during the work week for a healthier lunch option. Ordered the small chop chop salad.

I have a love/hate relationship with this place. I always say I'm not going back but somehow I always return. My favorite is the Mediterranean Salad. I have my specific ways I like my salad but they always forget :(. In example I say NO olives and they always forget. Or how about the day I found a bug in my salad. Sigh. They must be doing something back otherwise why would I return?!?

The sandwich quality is good, the value is so-so, and the execution is poor. I brought two co-workers here because the salads are high in all three categories and thus, seemingly, the sandwiches should be as well.

Last Thursday, I ordered a half-Mediterranean Salad/soup combination to-go, through the online service. After bringing it back to work, and consuming over half of my salad, I saw something I wish I didn't: a grasshopper the size of my pinkie was in my salad. It was repulsive and disgusting, and to think, I had eaten over half of the salad already. I brought the salad back to the restaurant, and asked to speak with the manager. She immediately threw my salad into the trash can without looking at my salad, and went on to explain to me the situation. She (Sarah) noted that these were organic salads, and thus, they did not have any pesticides. She also started inferring to me, that during the summer time, this type of situation tends to happen more often. I was repulsed by her casualness to the situation - she did not seem surprised at all, refunded the $10.00 I spent online on this salad and soup combination, and gave me a coupon for one free lunch. The casualness was almost to say that because the salads are organic, and that it is almost summer time, those who choose to eat at Cafe Venue should be aware that this sort of thing might happen.

OK, so I'm cheap and like to get a lot of bang for my buck.  So, whenever someone recommends a salad for lunch, my usual response used to be "No thank you, I'm not a rabbit and need more substinence than that."  In my mind, if I'm going to spend $8 or more on lunch (the usual fare in FiDi), it better have meat, carbs or something that will fill me up in it.  Thus, since most salads in the financial district cost more than $8 and do not usually contain meat or carbs, I didn't tend to eat salads.
Props for fast service and for reasonable lunch prices. Doesn't excuse a chop chop salad with both a fly *and* a spider mixed in.
Shatangi is a fan of fresh juice,

The sandwiches I've tried have been tasty and after having a salad today I want to try more of them. The line during the lunch rush is kind of a bummer. I'm going to start phone ordering from this place.
I been eating the chop chop salad for a good 10 years. I have been eating at Venue since it was one shop on Market street. The quality is high and the service is quick, love it.
Note that the 4 stars are subjective to vegetarian lunchtime sandwiches in the Financial District, not indicative of any other fare at this location.

I've been coming here for two years regularly for breakfast. While the service can vary, it ranges from competent to excellent. Staff really does seem to care what you think and generally cooks the simple dishes they make rather well.
Lunch was a huge pile of fibrous lettuce chunks, topped with a few cubes of beets and some candied nuts that I assume came out of a can. Pretty dismal stuff.
Had a pretty awful sandwich. Well below average.

We use Cafe Venue about twice a month to cater staff meetings. My colleagues love it, and say that the salads are really fresh and that the sandwiches are great. They also do really delicious desserts that we order on occassion.

I used to go here regularly and then stopped a few years ago when Mixt Greens opened up because they have better salad options. I thought I'd give Cafe Venue another try and quickly remembered the other reason I stopped going. They can get kind of pissy if you try to substitute or change anything. It clearly states on the menu that you can substitute the mixed greens in any of the salads. I had to repeat my order twice and the person still didn't get it and was kind of rude about it. I didn't have the patience to deal with attitude over different lettuce, so I turned around and left.  Back to Mixt Greens!

This is not the best Cafe Venu in the city by a long shot. Only come here in a serious jam and don't expect quality food or friendly service. I wouldn't say the staff is rude but they definitely are not interested in my business.
Great workday lunch place, good pasta and sandwiches (Monterey Chicken is yummy). Inexpensive, diligent service, can order online.

I walk by this place almost every weekday after being dropped off, casual carpooling from Alameda to SF.  Normally, I can make it to my job and get a little sustenance to tide me over for lunch, but this morning was an exception.  My stomach was growling - "feed me Carol...I'm hungry."
I get one thing here: small chicken caesar salad.
We were to celebrate a birthday dinner in October and could not have asked for a better dining experience.

A little hideaway, but a fabulous restaurant with excellent food and service. A secret that I learned: the kitchen that services the fine-dining restaurant is the same kitchen that services the bar! The food is consistently good, and the service is always strong. I love their spaghetti and their French onion soup. It's to die for! This place deserves more than 5 stars.

Located right across the street from the Hyatt, you can spot the place by it's small entrance with the blue awning. Since it's in downtown SF, there's only street metered parking or parking garages. The establishment is a 2.5 block walk away from Montgomery Bart or if you're driving, the Sutter-Stockton Garage and the White House Garage is about a block away.

While on trip to SF, decided to use the Michelin rankings for a couple of dining experiences.  Settled on Campton Place one night and Gary Dankos the next.  Campton Place was easy to find, being located in the Taj.  The environs were inviting with an open floor plan and adequate decor.  Went for broke and did the 9 course, "Degestation Menu".  The amuse-bouche was fantastic, we seemed to be off to a good start.  The Spice Pot was really interesting and tasty.  Found the remaining courses generally solid but the portions were small and overall nothing to write-home about.  The Tandoori Shrimp was very good, though again the protein seemed almost like an afterthought considering all the garnish.  The lobster was OK, the lamb and duck were cooked well.  The dessert was not memorable.  Overall, not the greatest fine dining experience.  Nothing terrible, but nothing all that memorable.  The wine selection was great with reasonable mark-ups.  In addition, though the staff overall was very polite, it seemed that after initially being attended to by our waiter and the hostess, we were then attended by a "B team" of assistants who seemed to come out of nowhere, presented a dish and then vanished, never to be seen again.  The restaurant did not seem busy, so I'm not certain why we were relegated to everyone but our waiter.  Went to Restaurant Gary Danko the next night.  Next time I'm in SF you'll find me there and not at Campton Place.  FYI, wore a jacket without a tie and noticed most wore tie or jacket.

Very disappointing and phenomenally expensive for what is presented. Wait staff were fine but unwilling to let me know the cost of the wine pairings - the pours were about 3 oz. of mediocre wines( Austrian gruner veltliner, Cal gewurztraminer, etc. - nothiing special) - 3 servings $85 per person. The sommelier went missing after first introduction and wait staff did not know much about the wine. The food was OK - nothing special except one appetizer served in a flowerpot, with dry ice at base which when water was poured in created a San Francisco fog effect - nice touch and dish was interesting. The other app - scallops was quite pedestrian as were mains and dessert. There was a conspicuous absence of vegetables with app and mains - which seems a characteristic of this restaurant. Five of six courses of spice route tasting menu  were animal protein based -- we avoided that. The various amuse bouches that appeared were very nice. Nice atmosphere but I expect more for $500 for two.

Once again, a perfect rating for its creative, quality food and impeccable service. We always have the vegetarian tasting menu and it is wonderful. If you want the best food and service, this is where to go. One of my best dining experiences ever!

We booked the private dining room for our wedding reception and dinner for a party of 14. Our private dining manager Virginia was amazing!!! She was flexible and went out of her way to help us organize and intimate and amazing experience on a very quick timeline.

Had lunch and it was great. One of the best french onion soups we've ever had! We ate in the bistro. Nice atmosphere and break from the chaos of union square. Their fries were were wonderful! As well as their Manhattan. Would definitely recommend.
I went to Camptom Place for my wedding rehearsal dinner. The food was amazing. I especially loved the lobster with curry appetizer, and mango tart.

Neither my husband nor I have ever tried a tasting menu so we thought we would go to a nice place without the kids and give it a try.  We both opted for the Spice Route six course tasting menu.  The food was very good, the presentation was amazing.  Ricardo our waiter could not have been nicer or more knowledgeable about the food or the wine.  We also selected the Premium Wine pairing.  Overall we had a very nice experience but I am not sure we will try a tasting anytime soon again.  The overall bill was 2 to 3x's what we would normally spend and I can't say we enjoyed our meal more than we would have if we had gone to another great restaurant and ordered one nice bottle of wine.  My husband actually left a little hungry (and he is not a big guy), I felt like the amount of food was perfect, it might have been psychological as the portions were small but still filling.  We were not happy with the wine - what do we know?  I enjoy strong red wines and because a lot of the food was centered around seafood the pairing were white and two were so sweet I could barely drink them - sweet wine yuck, just not for me.  I would say we both enjoyed the meal, really enjoyed the wait staff and the overall atmosphere but likely will not try something similar in the future, a bit too pricey compared to other amazing meals we have had.  I would rate the atmosphere and service a 5, the food a 4, the wine a 3 and the value a 2.5.

Perfect all around.  We originally thought we were going with the 5 course tasting menu but decided we were all more tired than normal so wanted to go faster. We went with the 3 course and the Campton staff did a perfect job on pacing.  It never felt rushed but they kept things moving along, which is credit to them - I think they could tell we were all in the mood to move faster.

Great Indian fusion restaurant - perfect dining spot after shopping at Union Sq. Some food is on a spicier side - check with the waiter. Wide selection of wines - their wine list is probably around 50 pages long!
Amazing food! So creative and delicious! Best Indian fusion restaurant that I have been to..
Chef Srijith is arguably one of the best chefs in San Francisco. The food was decadent without being fatty. Each sauce was rich with flavor and unique.

The food itself is amazing!! The fusion of the herbs, spices, and entrées are exquisite. My wife and I were celebrating our 4 year wedding anniversary, and were warmly greeted by exceptional service and lovely gifts. Our server was extremely helpful,  friendly,  and provided a great experience to our evening. My wife and I had the 6 course meal and undoubtedly recommend it to anyone. There is a wide variety of tasteful wines that pefectly pair up w/ each of the courses. And the courses can be easily substituted for another item upon request, as the service is very pleasing towards any dietary restrictions you may have. Overall wonderful!!

We celebrated our second wedding anniversary here. We got a last-minute reservation when the place we had originally booked called me a few days before to tell me they couldn't accommodate my dietary restrictions they had previously said would be no problem (gee, thanks). As you can tell from the star rating, I'm very glad we ended up here.   It was one of the best meals we've ever had and is now up there with Acquerello as my favorite SF restaurant.

Located in the Taj Campton Place Hotel, this Cal-Indian restaurant with one Michelin Star has impeccable service and creative dishes. We came here on Sunday for lunch, and they have brunch and lunch menu options as well as a three courses menu that you can choose 1 appetizer, 1 entree, and 1 dessert from the a la carte menu for $50.
This place didn't begin my tasting menu with bread... which is both a gift and a curse.

In regards to restaurants, I am pretty much a follower. I like to go where people say I should go, except I have never heard people talk about this place. Maybe it is because it is a $$$$ restaurant and my friends are more like $$ or $$$ people, but this place should be on the list of "must goes". It was delicious, the service was great and really it was one of the more affordable Michelin 1s I have gone to. We went and got the 3 course meal for about $75 (not bad) and the chef still gave us various small plates on the house. It was a great experience. Service was terrific. and don't even get me started on how comfortable the booths are. OMG. it is like sitting on a cloud. You want to fall asleep there and never leave.
Campton Place offers a variety of unique, delicious tasting menus.  Recently, my wife, son and I had dinner here and all of us were extremely satisfied with our meals.

Delightful, impeccable settings and service. Perfectly cooked and beautiful plated food. Liked the halibut with fava bean best (not pictured here, as camera somehow ate this up, too). How is it that I walked by this place for 2 years and never ventured in?? I would have stopped in quite a few times by now. What a special place!
Overall I really enjoyed my dinner here. There were a couple minor annoyances, but for the most part it was a solid evening.

Happened upon this little gem by searching for Michelin Star restaurants within walking distance of the Curran Theatre, and Michelin, you did not disappoint!  We had the theatre menu and I was admittedly a little nervous as my boyfriend is not a huge fan of tasting menus having left hungry on several occasions.  The portions were not huge but completely satisfying and combined with the amuse bouche offerings, we left with comfortably full stomachs and zinging taste buds.  We started with delicious, unique cocktails (refreshing cucumber and a lychee spiced one) and then had a glass of wine each.  Very decent offerings by the glass and half bottle and the full bottle menu is very comprehensive, almost overwhelmingly.  I had the lobster appetizer and my BF had the the scallops, both very delicious with very interesting flavour combinations.  My lobster was a little on the tough side but not enough to disappoint.  I then had the duck breast with a rhubarb compote, perfectly balanced sweet and sour and the duck was cooked to perfection.  My BF had the steak with truffle sauce and while he thought it was a little undercooked, I think it was right on medium rare and he ate every bite.  We decided to try one of each of the dessert offerings and while they weren't the best desserts we've ever had, they were quite tasty and the presentation was amazing. The star of the night was the vanilla bean smoke flavoured ice cream, we both could not get over how it tasted and felt in our mouths.  Overall, amazing experience and I would most definitely go back.  The chandelier is pretty amazing too and the booths are super cushy comfortable, definitely use the pillow provided as back support though!
My pal Michael Bauer happens to agree:

The service was as expected for a restaurant of this caliber - professional, polished, well-timed.  Except for the sommelier, who was kinda awkward with us.  We know our way around the book, so that wasn't a problem.

I came here with my fellow Yelper friend Michelle L. for a workday lunch date...perfect excuse to go out for Dine About Town. We snagged a reservation via OpenTable but it wasn't really necessary as the restaurant was pretty empty upon arrival at 12:15pm.

Absolutely one of my favorite meals. The French Indian cooking technique is great. Brings the best of french preparation and spices from India. We had 6 courses and 2-3 in between mini courses. My only complaint is that I didn't get a room in the hotel because the drive back had me almost passing out!
Was here today for Dine About Town lunch.  Rather disappointing, especially given that it received a Michelin star.

Had one of the best dining experiences in my life.  The food, service, and ambiance was one of the best.  Well deserving of the Michelin star and actually better than the two star experience I recently had.
Going to check off my Michelin star list, we decided to come here for brunch and shop in Union Square.
The bar is amazing. Great drinks to pre party for the night. Calamari was pretty awesome.
It is pricy but worth a money!
Phenomenal dining experience and true service. Highly recommend for haute cuisine and with an expense account.
Campton Place certainly lived up to expectations.  It certainly isn't fusion cuisine, but more modern cuisine infused with Indian ingredients.  Very pleasant to say the least.

Im surprised at the 4 star rating here? I love getting their filet. Me and my boyfriend had our first date here so that alwAys bring back goood memories ( also valentines ) their filet was perfectly cooked medium rare. Juicy and soft. Hands down the best filet around!!!!!!!! Also, i was really really impressed by the service at this place!!  Overall delicious food, fancy atmosphere, good service! Def no complaints.

It's good and up to par for the city. Nothing special. I came for brunch on a Friday. It's nice and quiet on the first floor of the hotel. It makes for a nice meal if you're just looking for a sit down place, but if you're looking for novelty and special occasions? I would go else where.

We did the wine/food pairing and I want to say that I really enjoyed all the food but to be honest, I'm writing this review a couple weeks later and not one thing stands out as memorable.  Considering it is $95 a person, this isn't a good thing.  The service was good and kept things flowing.  I'd say out of everything I tasted the lobster was the best.  I couldn't have the black cod and so they supplemented it with duck which was also good.  The desserts were weird and I didn't even finish one.  As for the wine, I get that they were supposed to go with the food as it is a pairing but there was only one red and out of all the whites, I only liked one.  The rest were way too sweet for me.  Many others at the table agreed except one in the group who really enjoyed the wine.  Overall, I left feeling pretty disappointed and while the food was good, there are just so many better options in the city in my opinion.

Had a great experience here. Both of us got the Spice Route menu (and who doesn't? As far as I could tell, every other table ordered the same thing as well). The chef is inventive and understands the interaction between salty, spicy, and sweet flavors. One thing I don't like about some Michelin starred restaurants is they tend to emphasize creamy and sweet flavors; not here. Similar to All Spice, the food is Indian fusion or modern Indian.
This was the fanciest Indian food I've ever had.  And I was impressed with everything.  Great service and flavorful food.

An absolutely delicious dining experience.  The service is impeccable from start to finish.  The Chefs Spice menu was amazing.  Each course was very flavorful with various spices and textures.  Incredible presentation.  The wine paring was perfect.  Definitely a great treat.

Why bother leaving a review for Lee's Deli? I mean it's not like anyone there is looking at Yelp for guidance on their customer service or food quality. I've been coming to one Lee's or the other throughout my professional career in the FiDi and SoMa. Job changes. Promotions. Layoffs. Lee's has been more constant than my career. And it's not as if I'm going to stop going there for any particular reason. If I want a $2.75 Onion Bagel with Chive or Garlic Shmear, there I'll be. If I want a $4.35 Chicken Salad Sandwich on Sliced Sourdough, I'm right there in line even if they do charge an arbitrary 35-cents for cucumber slices. Who needs service with a smile anyway?

Lee's has a little bit of everything...salad bar, hot Asian cuisine bar, traditional subs made to order, Vietnamese subs made to order, burgers, wraps, traditional soups, and Vietnamese noodles. The counters are clean and the service is quick and friendly.
GREASY BASICS

Love Lee's for lunch. Their steamed fish with ginger and green onions is a heathy and tasty treat. Pair it with their fresh hot veggies and a spicy tuna roll and you've got yourself a delicious lunch. It is always consistent and fresh!

Until today I was a daily customer.  Egg and Cheese on a Bagel.  But it is now $3.59 cents.  I am not saying that this is outrageous, but let's think about this.  It is a toasted bagel, microwaved egg, and American Cheese.

Lee's Deli somehow manages to offer the mediocre of everything. I was very excited by their concept, and I saw a lot of potential in their business model. However, I feel that Lee tries to do too much without offering anything good enough to come back for.
Definitely just got food poisoning from their noodles right before happy hour on a FRIDAY.

My review is for the salad bar only. I always have a big, filling salad for lunch --  I'm a Mixt Greens devotee. But I've been trying to cut my spending lately, and $12 every day for lunch was adding up. So I've started visiting the salad bar at Lee's. It's been a very pleasant surprise. I wish they had some freshly-made dressings as options (they're all very cornstarch-y and clearly came out of a bottle), but my salad is always satisfactory, and they have a good variety of veggies, many options for protein toppings (hardboiled eggs, tofu, chickpeas), avocados (yum), and the service is fast and friendly (even when the line is long, it moves quickly). Most importantly, the large salad I get usually ends up being $8-9. A similarly-sized salad at Wildflower Cafe, the most comparable salad bar in the neighborhood, runs me about $12-13. Lee's is great and I'm happy to have them in the neighborhood.

I don't know why I never noticed, but they have a noodle soup section where you order from the cooks who (re)cook your noodles right in front of you.  This is the best place for ramen in the area.  Might be a sad fact that a Chinese deli makes the best ramen within a 4 block radius, but hey, it says something about Lee's good business model and operational acumen.  But it also indicates the dearth of good ramen shops in SF.  Don't worry, I used "dearth" correctly.  Look it up, I dare ya.

This is lee's on roids! Still have sandwiches, soups, salad bar... But you have a lot more, way more. There is a nice hot bar with a great selection of food and dim sum. You still have the same non-friendly people working here but I've grown to like that. It's become part of the charm if you will. This place also has tables and counters if you wanted to eat here. Probably not the place for a first date or any date unless you are working towards a divorce. For lunch, especially if you have no clue in what you want then go here and let your eyes and nose pick for you.

Ordered (6) assorted cronuts yesterday to pick up this morning at 9AM. The woman at the counter wrote down the order, which also included my contact information. Went to pick up the order at 9AM this morning and they gave my order away to someone else!!! WTF!!!  I wanted to surprise my sister-in-law for her birthday this evening since she's wanted to try a cronut for the past few weeks. What a bummer. Will not order ANYTHING from this Lee's again. Luckily Illy's down the street had bomboloni (Italian donuts) which probably has better quality food anyway.
Lees deli definitely tops my list for salad bars. Factors contributing are

Been years since I have eaten at Lee's.  I think the last time I did, their tuna sandwich was $2.50.  I have for a while held a high-importance in my workday lunch so never really thought it worthy of my stomach.  However, I noticed recently a sign advertising Vietnamese Sandwiches sold here now so decided to try today as I was looking for something quick.  It's actually a very nice version of the sandwich.  I had pork.  It's probably less Vietnamese than most as the pork has more of a non-ethnic taste to it, but it's a good flavor and the bread was fresh and good consistency.  Veggies were cold and crisp.  Amount was perfect for not being too full and saltiness was a good level.  Price is right at $3.95+ tax.  They had a sign saying how the Franchise Tax Board browbeated them into charging tax that they claimed they already did but included in the price and remitted to the state, but now have to itemize it.  I'm sure they did not do so, but I appreciated them being pissed and keeping priced down all those years.  Still, price is good as I've paid double for worse Viet Sandwiches at other places.  Also a plus is the large space so even at prime time, you can count on not being squished or having a giant line.  I might give their burger and fries a try another time now that they have won me over a bit with this visit.

Spied a box of Pasteurized Egg Product here this morning -- is this what most egg breakfasts are cooked from?  What else here is made from pre-processed ingredients?  (I guess I always suspected, but never really wanted to know)
No stars. There was a worm in my soup!

Ook, man. I've seen better breakfast at homeless shelters. Lee's breakfast buffet is some rough stuff. They do what I call "industrial eggs", I dunno if they're powdered or not, but they're cooked together in this giant block in a pan, such that you end up having to scoop out gross drippy chunks. Ech.

I Love the variety of selection of Chinese food. There are so many to choice from . It is easy and simple. The food is fresh and warm.  It's a good choice for lunch  if you want to grab something fast .

This is the crown prince of Lee's Delis within walking distance of my office, which is kind of like saying something is the shiniest turd.    C'mon, everyone knows what Lee's is all about--cheap, decent food, sold with lightening fast cashiers.
Lee's management responded with better speed and professionalism than most major corporations, provided a full explanation, an apology and a refund.  Thanks, Lee's - I will be back!
Hmm...did I click on another Lee's Deli location because I'm almost sure I've reviewed them before.  Oh well!  Love their self-serve food as well as their sammiches!

wanted to try  lees deli that surrounds our building., I have to say . i was surprised by the variety. but let down on the quality. The food felt like it sat out for a while,  The many samples of food i tasted dry.  I was the price was a little iffy . For what i grabbed . It weighed out to 1lb. which came out to $7 and some change. For a small person to finish all of it and didnt feel full, that caught me off gaurd.
My new "go-to" for lunch.  I can grab a healthy salad or grab some not so healthy fried food.  Either way I'm happy and it usually costs me around $10.

Lee's is a solid choice if you want to grab a quick and cheap lunch (or even dinner).  The sandwiches are very plain-Jane, but you get them in a hurry, and they are super cheap.  The salad bar (with all kinds of other hot and cold goodies) is also a solid value at $6.95 per pound, but don't expect lobster salad and freshly carved roast beef, but the roast chicken in the hot bar is really solid.  Did I mention that this place is a great value....
Good prices, excellent food for a buffet.

There are Lee's deli everywhere in SF. This one is by far the best one. Jook, Chinese food, dim sum, noodle bar, salad bar, soup bar, sandwich bar... you name it, they probably have it. The food is pretty good for what you can get for quick to-go place. The seating area feels like a cafeteria but it's a good place to pick up lunch for sure!

Haha when I first saw Lee's Deli I thought it was a joke. "Sushi by the pound?!" I found out that, yes, they were very serious.  Bring a bucket and pay for nearly everything by the pound (including white rice).  The buffet food is good, not great, but gets the job done, and there's a huge selection which has minor changes from day to day.  The sandwiches are actually amazing, as are the soups (and really cheap too).  I have not been brave enough to try the sushi yet, and don't plan on it any time soon.
One word: Jook. They know how to do it.

Go-to spot for a quick and cheap bite to eat. Some locations are slightly different from others but the Battery location is the biggest one closest to me and they have a huge variety of different food.

So I usually love coming to Lee's! Their sandwiches are really yummy! So for a while I was going there for breakfast & getting their oatmeal since it wasn't very exspensive! Well one time I was eating it and felt something in my mouth! Then spit out a fingernail! I almost puked in my mouth! So gross!! I called them right away to inform them, but when someone answered the phone they acted like they didn't speak any English and dismissed me! Ever since I have never been back to this location and will never eat their oatmeal again! I probably won't be eating their soup either cause who knows what will be floating in there!!
There are days when I say to my colleagues, "Oh I'm just heading out to grab a salad for lunch," when truly I'm craving something fried. That's when Lee's Deli comes in handy.

You can find a Lee's Deli almost everywhere in FiDi.  The great thing about Lee's is that if you're craving something in particular, they might actually carry it.  Breakfast, sandwiches, burgers, soup, salad, sushi, salad, Chinese food.. They carry it all.  It is just quite convenient sometimes.  The ladies who handle the registers there are really good at getting people through the lines, so don't worry if you see a lot of people waiting.. You'll be out of there in no time.  It's cafeteria-style seating, if you don't want to bring your food back to the office.

Went here for oatmeal and they were out so instead bought $5-6 of a small box of eggs and bacon.  Of course everything in the Fidi are expensive.  However, their  tonkatsu flavor ramen is only $5, the presentation looks nice.  Of course at that price, I was expecting really bad ramen, well.. the broth was not too warm, but for that price, I was happy for what I got, the bowl was not too small, but of course you cannot expect quality at that price, so I would order that again.
Just what the doctor didn't order: Low quality fast food whose sole mission is to fill the belly (in more ways than one.)
Basic Lunch - A two you would go back to because of convenience.
Worst. Ramen. Ever.

If you had to rate each thing they do they'd probably get a 3 for each one. Ok chinese food. Ok dim sum. Ok salad bar. Ok Deli. The wonton soup I actually love from here. But put it all together and add the robot cashiers who move at superhuman speed to get you rung up and back to work, and this place garners 4 stars.

Where else can you mix Dim Sum with their Salad Bar?  The sign saids please don't mix hot food with their salad bar, but the cashiers don't care.  I love this place in terms of time, waiting is mininum and the sandwich ladies are quick.  Not the best in quality, but who cares, they are cheap.

I walk a mile or so to work each morning after I get off MUNI at Montgomery Station. I know, I know: it's not so far, and it is good exercise, and blah, blah, blah. And there is actually a bus, too. But none of this matters. It still bums me out.  If I could get my walk to work in the mornings a Yelp review, it would get 2 stars.
For breakfast tater tots and sausage are great here! Very cheap, food is fresh, and lots of variety. They have everything here, salads, sandwiches, bagels, chinese food.
LOVE LOVE LOVE the club sandwich!! For $5 bucks, it's HUGE! More than enough to use up two of your meal times in one day.

The pros are that they have a good selection of food, its quick and they have some healthy food options (kind of). So if this is what you're looking for, then this is your place. The cons are that the healthier cooked food is a little oily and the place is a little pricey for the quality of food you get. If you want the healthier options, stick to the cold veggies and away from the cooked ones. Overall, not a great place and not a bad place but a good place to mix it up.

I used to think this place was pretty rad for the ultimate indecisive FiDi lunch hunter, but now I just feel sad and taken advantage of. Three California roll pieces, 8 green beans, less than half a cup of Korean yam noodles = $7.88. And this is considered getting out of there lucky. I've known people who have easily spent $15 to $20, not fully understanding how heavy their container is and how overly priced Julie's Kitchen is.
This review is based on price, taste and convenience to my office.
An ok spot I guess if you want variety for lunch.  I was pleasantly surprised by all the choices, but the price per pound is too expensive for me.

Food was good - good variety and flavor. However, the turkey meatball that I ate midway through the meal was raw on the inside. Not just pink, but mushy raw. I told the manager, she proceeds to take the meatball off my plate with a gloved hand and dump it in the trash, grabs the rest of my plate and weighs it, and then says "you go get 2.28 dollars of food." I ask if she'll check the other meatballs and that I don't feel comfortable eating the other food since I was just served salmonella. No offer of refund and no apology, they didn't even check the other meatballs. Gross. Unfortunate as the food isn't bad.

DON"T go after 1pm. That's about the time they begin to abandon the buffet and not refill. By 1:45 almost half the selection is gone or empty. The food is very good and expensive. Much better food than Lee's if you get there early
Especially not bad if you're doing paleo. Had 5 different types of meat, some squash, and spinach. All for less than a pound, or around $8.50. Nearby public, outdoor seating is nice.

I used to really like this place, even though it's very pricey.  But I ate there two weeks ago and had what was labelled red snapper. I spent the rest of the afternoon running to the bathroom about every 30 minutes!  I have read about many restaurants labelling the escolar fish as snapper and other fish.  Feel free to look online about the unhappy side-effects of eating escolar.  Anyhow, over the past two weeks, I emailed Julie's Kitchen and tried calling several times to ask about their fish and whether it was really escolar.  So far no one has responded.  Poor way to do business considering how much they charge!

The foods great, it is just ridiculously expensive!  If this place was just slightly cheaper it would be AMAZING!  They have a very interesting selection of food!  Everything from salad and fresh fruit to sushi to steak and macaroni and cheese!  If only this place was a little less pricey!

Expensive for business lunch buffet, but the good thing is that they have more kinds of seafood compared to others. My lunch came up to about $9 which is twice expensive than the indian buffet a couple of blocks away. Not worth it, in my opinion. Will not come back
TL; DR: Good salad bar, but EXTREMELY expensive.
Way expensive for what you get.  One piece of tofu, one piece of sushi and a spoonful of pasta was $7. Won't go there again.

3.5 stars. This place isn't that bad. I heard so many mix reviews and finally decided to try it. They have a huge selection of food. I didn't eat the sushi stuff, but all the cook food and salad was really good. So much variety. It is really expensive though. I'm not the type to complain about how much food costs, but this was a little much. Over $12 just for a few items.......I heard if you guess the correct weight, you get your food for free. You can't be off by .01 pounds either. It's pretty hard to get it exactly.
(comment from 2013 visit)

I've seen so many good reviews & finally tried it today...  I have to say I am disappointed.  The foods are really not very good and the price is crazily expensive.  There is sushi, but they are not all that.  This is a little better than Lee's but the price is 3 times more.  Not worth it.  Oh and on top of that, there was a mouse hanging around trying to get into the garbage near the entrance.  My first & last time there.
I always find very healthy organic food here with superb variety in choice.

I just had lunch here and I thought the food was great. The salmon sushi was very fresh and tasted buttery, the caprese salad was tasty and the mango was ripe and delicious. Yes, it's expensive, but you get what you pay for and I think this place is worth the $9.99 a pound.

A few months ago, I would have given this 4 stars.  But as Biggie said, "Things Done Changed". A "Warning" to customers out there. Cashiers may be too lazy to void transactions and will just basically say "Gimme the Loot".
"Better than Lee's" but at triple the price.
JC gets a bad rap for being more expensive. Compared to Lee's or some of these other weigh as you go places, the quality here is undeniable.
+.04 ...so close to this place being a cost effective lunch place, but sadly, I guessed the weight of my meal incorrectly and paid an arm and a leg (~$15 for 1.39lbs, $0 if guessed right).

I had lunch at Julie's for the first time yesterday.  There is a huge range of offerings on the buffet... I went for sushi, salad, soba noodles, cooked salmon, spare ribs, chicken, and potatoes.  Yes, I am a pig.  My salad weighed in at 1.80 pounds.  That was the downside... At $9.95 per pound it made for an expensive lunch + afternoon snack, but then again most people aren't gluttons like me and sushi at $9.95 per pound may not be a bad deal.

I've always been torn about this place.  They have a great selection of food and entrees however it in too expensive for a salad bar.  A few years ago I used to go to this place all the time, now there are so many more options in the Financial District that you can be a little more picky and explore your options.  I would definitely go back, but keep in mind as your plate fills up, your pockets empty.

I go here often during my lunch hour. Always fresh food, really nice selection. Everything is clean and tidy. Staff is very fast and friendly. They are usually super packed during lunch rush, but the cashiers are fast and efficient. They keep the line moving and quickly! It's sort of small in there so during lunch rush it can be tough to grab a table but I've only had to stand around a few times waiting for one to free up (only a moment or so). Definitely a decent amount of tables and seating though so no big deal overall.

The food was okay, but I am quite irritated about their "free lunch" policy.  There's a big sign above the cash register that says "Guess the weight or price of your lunch, and it's free!"  So I guessed that my plate was one pound.  The woman weighed it, and it came out to .99 pounds.  She said my lunch wouldn't be free, because I hadn't guessed exactly one pound.  In other words, because I was off by .01 pounds, or less than 1/6th of an ounce, my guess didn't count.  Without some margin of error ("Within half an ounce," "within .01 pound," etc.), there's no way anyone can ever get a free lunch, and the whole thing is a sham.  That really pisses me off.

Eaten there at least once a week for the past 6 years.  The place is very consistent and serves pretty fresh food.  It is a great option if you're trying to eat healthy which is hard around the financial district and you can always get a smaller portion of the good stuff (great lasagna and tempura shrimp).

Julie's food is fabulous!  The price per pound is high, so I get some of the items (there are plenty) that justify the high cost like sushi, shrimp, beef, etc.  The price per pound is posted right above the buffet line.  No one else has the variety of Julie's.
If you want a little Vegas in your San Francisco, then come here. The buffet has sushi and steak and fancy things like that...

The food gets three stars, but the price is definitely a downside. I work down the street from this restaurant, and I thought that the price-per-pound idea was pretty cool, but I was wary because they didn't have the actual price per pound posted anywhere in the restaurant. Today, I was in the mood for sushi and I knew they had it, so I went. The sushi looked delicious, but it lacked flavor. I also got some pot stickers, which looked nice and crispy on the platter, but were warm and squishy when I took a bite. To round out my plate, I got a dollop of mac n cheese, which was pretty good. In total, I got 4 pieces of sushi, 2 small pot stickers, and a dollop of mac n cheese, and it came to $8.85. That's outrageous. I would have priced that amount of food at $6-7 at the very most.
quick lunch. Not too many choices maybe because they were almost closing, but all their food seen  fresh. I enjoyed my salad.
Decent food but incredibly expensive.
Never again.

No matter what I eat here I get the shits hardcore.  Stuff is left out a little too long in my honest opinion, and I'd be ill-pressed to call any of their "sushi" actual fish or cuts from fish they advertise them to be (escolar anyone?!?!).

Went there at 12:30p on a Monday afternoon.  I got mostly sake sushi because  everything else looked like a mess.  Meats looked uncooked, dry,and raw.  The poached salmon looked dry and hard.  Place is sort'a going downhill and that's sad since it used to be one of my favorites.  They are capabable of so much better.  If they don't change things they will have the same fate as the Jamba Juice next door.
Overpriced. And way too much sodium in everything.
I'm sitting here with a half eaten plate of food unable to contain my negative feelings for a $12 lunch that is just plain INEDIBLE.

The food is OK, I guess.  The one star rating is for the price.  I have lived in SF for 14 years so I am used to paying idiot prices for food.  but seriously?  today I got 1/2 cup white rice, some spinach salad, a few steamed carrots and a piece of chicken smaller than a deck of cards and it was $9.00.  that's just ridiculous. My to-go container was so light I almost forgot I was carrying it - for $9.00.   Epic fail, Julies' Kitchen.  I'll not be back again.  (ps - Urban Picnic has a LUCIOUS bowl of Pho for $9.75 - i'll take my business there).

This place is right by my work so it's really convenient to grab something healthy yet yummy. It's about $9.95/pound that serves from salad, sushi, and hot foods.  I would give it a try if you're around the Fi-Di.
i love the selection here.

too expensive for food that is not exciting nor very tasty...$11 for a little bit of salad greens, some marinated mushrooms and about 4 ounces of salmon which I had to cover with sriracha to give it flavor...I dont think I need to go back there.

I popped into Banana House in the middle of a weekday lunch rush.  I've had this place, along with several other Belden Place establishments, bookmarked for months.  Although they were busy, I was determined to tough it out and try their lunch takeout.
Not worth it..! Rice $2 small serving of entree $13- why so pricey? What's so special?!?!
I knew I shouldn't have ignored the 3-stars on yelp.

I gave this place another chance since my friend was craving thai food. I told her no, but that was the closest place for thai. My before experience was gross. Gross customer service, gross food. Anyways, it has not changed, the water is not even cold, the waitress takes forever to bring me hot sauce. (Isn't the hot sauce suppose to be on the table anyways?) Now, the waitress doesn't even say "thank you" when we leave.  It's still a no go. Still giving us the check in the middle of eating! If you are big on being treated nicely, great customer service, and having and getting respect, don't go here!

I got their Papaya salad for lunch today. It was super liquidy. It had lumps of sugar or jaggery or something like that. The lettuce was soggy(ew!). The shrimp tasted a little stale. The salad was also very stinky. I have a cup of cinnamon tea on my desk to get rid of that smell.
We get there on a Sunday afternoon. The restaurant nearly empty. We sat and wait for the next 15 min for someone to come get our orders and bring us water. Nothing. So we left.

Came here for lunch with my coworkers and since we had a large group (party of 7), we got a table in the basement. I had the duck curry with brown rice which was decent, although the coconut juice left much to be desired.
I went to this place for a to-go dinner order. It was very empty but several people were waiting for their take-away food.

I probably should have verified when my order for one entree and a Thai Iced tea came out to ~$18, but they gave me shrimp instead of the beef I ordered (which right off the bat was an extra three dollars). Didn't bother asking them to fix my order because I had waited at least 20 minutes for take out.

this place is a DUMP.  it constantly smells like bleach or piss and if you sit downstairs it is like a dungeon.  two thai places around fidi closed and sucks that this place is open now.  always check your credit card statements because they double charged me.  place is totally shady.

I was so hungry and there aren't a lot of options in the area on a Sunday afternoon. I start digging into my food. And as I start digging more into my steamed rice, I see a little black thing. Hungry, I pick it out and toss it, and continue to grub. But no, I dig further down the container, and black pebble like things throughout the container. They don't clean their food properly. Gross! Waste of money!

Ew. The people are nice but the food is disgusting. I lived in Thailand for a while and am a huge Thai food fan - this is not good Thai food. Ordered the pad se ew - and it was burnt. Pieces of black char on the noodles and veggies. The summer rolls were literally pieces of tofu in this weird rice roll that was kind of grainy - not the typical rice wrap you'd see for summer rolls. Disgusting, I couldn't even eat it. And they charged me $3 extra for shrimp ($11 for summer rolls when you can get it for $6-7 anywhere else with shrimp included). They forgot to give me the rice with the pad ka prow....the only thing that was good (very good) was the mango with sticky rice.
I came on a Monday during lunch hour (12:30) and ordered take out.  It was bustling but they still got my order out in a very reasonable amount of time.
first time being there for lunch on weekday. pad kee maw with seafood (shrimp & mussels)
I had the banana house ground chicken special on recommendation. A bit different than what I've seen on typical Thai menus which is nice. Taste was good. Not the cleanest place though.
3 stars average sounds about right for this place.
Staff was very polite and helpful. Very cramped place so get cozy!

Good, quick service. Tasty food and reasonable price. In the Finanical District, Chinatown area, Banana House is a good option (and costs less than the "fancy" chain Thai restaurant that has bastardized Thai food and has much higher prices).

Pretty good Thai place on Kearny, Banana House offers food I usually crave for dinner at lunchtime. The restaurant is cute: white table clothes atop little tables, wood walls, big windows. The wait staff is nice, fast, and attentive.

Kind of just average. I ordered my usual Thai dish - pad see ew. I quite enjoyed the soup that they served with it which was pretty unconventional for Thai places. It was some type of onion/vegetable blend that was pretty tasty. The pad see ew wasn't as flavorful as I would have liked, but it wasn't as bad as many others that I've tried before. The chicken was very tender and they were generous with the vegetables in the dish. The decor and service were both average.
Setting isn't the most trendy or updated but the food is excellent and the price is good. We got the Green Curry Beef and Pad Kee Mow. Great choices with flavor and balanced spice.
There's nothing spectacular yet inherently bad about this restaurant. The decor is simple and leaves much to be desired - not much of a Thai feel can be found.

I don't know why Banana House only has 3 stars, I've been coming here since I worked in the Financial District and I've never had an issue with them. They're always really nice to me and make sure I have everything I need.
This place is not bad if you want some quick Thai food in FiDi. I always want to come back for more to support the friendly Thai family/friends that run this store. :)

Ordered pad see ew.....and didn't like it. I've tried this dish in many Thai places, so I know what to expect. The worst part: the meat. It was baaad... On top of that....small serving portions. I left hungry. The staff was friend tho. Not coming back.

I ordered my fave thai dish- the infamous Pad See Ewe with tofu and no eggs. It wasn't bad and the portion was just right for someone getting dinner after a nice workout. Nice enough people. Not sure if I would make it a point to come back.

Decent Thai food in the financial district.  But lots of competition around, and there is nothing particularly special about this place that distinguishes it.  They have everything you are used to, but if it were me, I would take the hike and go to King of Thai a few blocks away if possible.

Wow hate to break it to you but this was terrible.  I ordered the pad kee mao which was supposed to have broccoli, tomato, basil and bell pepper and tofu.  Instead, it had only rice noodles, broccoli (with the stems and leaves..that's not basil) and the worst tofu I've had in years.  There was literally a point that I was mid chew on a tofu cube and decided to forego and spit out my mouthful into a napkin to throw away.  No flavor, cold and disgusting.  Definitely won't be coming back here.  Sad because I love Thai...
This place is Ehhh!
This place really seemed like authentically cooked Thai food.  It didn't have that mass produced or frufry over-the-top chic Thai presentation that you see in Ohio or Pittsburgh.
This is the second time I'm ignored there. They are not 1-person table-friendly. I've tried to go for lunch, but in today's case, left with an empty belly and a scowl on my face.

2 Thai restaurants on the same block. I will give Banana house the edge over Bangkok Express. The food was much better. Against my better judgement, I ordered the fried rice and fried chicken dish. Yeah I know, not very healthy.  But it was pretty good. They did mess up my friend's order and got him the chicken pad see ew instead of the tofu pad see ew that he ordered. No harm, no fowl, it happens.
Stopped in on a whim on my walk to work. Reasonable prices, great Pad Thai and excellent staff! My glass never went empty, service was quick, and they were very kind. I'll definitely be back!

Huge, delicious crab rangoons. Prik Sod is scrumptious with a bit of spice from the jalapenos. Thai Iced Tea is one of the best I've had in San Franciso. I definitely recommend for lunch in FiDi or if you are feeling lazy and want takeout for dinner (as I did tonight, ha!).

Right when we walked in, it looked really dirty and disorganized. The waitress didn't understand English much and we had to ask for refills and utensils multiple times. Food wasn't any special. Never go back again.
Decent lunch portions. They're very flexible about the items you get (allowing for half and half of rice and pad thai).
The calamari is wierd.  It's all batter.  The food is really greasy.  I don't think I need to elaborate.
The pumpkin curry is good but that's about it. Their other food is average and you can get better quality at Osha's. It's always crowded so you need a reservation.

Stumbled upon this gem when the restaurant across the way couldn't seat us. Went with a group of 8 people. Everyone loved what they got. I got the tofu satay appetizer. Best peanut sauce I've had. Would go back! Again and again.
Not much spazzy flavor to Thai cuisine!

Get their veggie breakfast bagel. Even if you're not vegetarian, it's still delicious. You choose the type of bagel and spread (cream cheese or hummus), and it's topped with sprouts, tomato, cucumbers, and potentially more but I forget. They toast the bagel so it's all warm but the veggies are still fresh and crisp. Delicious and fairly cheap!

ah, the main tower deli. This place is a staple of my work week. I happen to work in the same building, so it's ultra convenient to pop in here for a bagel and coffee in the morning, or run down and grab something hot for lunch on days I don't feel like bravin g the FiDi crowds. The food is decently priced with good selection- I'm a fan of the falafel wrap and the Cool Ranch Chicken myself. The breakfast burritos are pretty damn good for eggs cooked on a panini press (seriously), and the bagels are hot, toasted and full of yummy cream cheese. I miss the fountain sodas, but the guys behind the counter are happy to grab you a cup of ice to go with your can or bottle of Diet Coke, should you need it. It's basic, it's simple, it's cheap. Seating is plentiful, the service is friendly and fast- what more could you want?
I have had at least 7 meals here.  All have been excellent.
I eat lunch here at least twice a week. The food is fresh and the dudes hustle. Not much more you can ask.
Found this place just by chance. You can't see this off any main street so they must get foot traffic by all the workers in the nearby buildings.
Just had a Vegan Wrap.  It was Killer.  Definitely coming back to this spot.
$8 for the daily special is a nice price, food was good. Went there with 5 friends, every one enjoyed their food. Good price/quality.
$7.58 for the Giants burger, on an unusual bread. Very nice quality/price ratio, and a bonus: very close to my new office :)

All the food is good. They have a nice variety of breakfast items (bagels, breakfast burritos, etc), the coffee is good, fresh OJ. And their lunches are good with a variety of sandwiches/ specials. Usually you can get a combo special for lunch for like $7. Pretty good prices for downtown!

In the city for a meeting I stopped here for breakfast.  The service was great, folks really friendly, and food was good.  Prices are decent.  I see they have a lunch buffet set up but I didn't have time to try that.  I would recommend this place if your on this side of financial district.

So I was looking for what used to be here but now it's called Main Tower instead of Nazdak Cafe since it's in the Schwab building.  Anyhow, I was here for the breakfast burrito and it's pretty good here.  The egg is tasty and you get a good amount of cheese in the burrito.  Otherwise, it's pretty standard fare, but a solid option if you work in the building.  I also saw my friend @jmk on CNN while eating here - random!
I had a turkey melt on sour dough and it was really really good. I will be going here and trying more of the menu in the future, but for now this place is really great.

Man oh man oh man....oh man. What can I say about Chipotle, that Chipotle doesn't already exude. I'll go into a play-by-play so you Yelpers out there get that passionate, pristine, and accurate portrayal if what to expect.

This has to be the worst Chipotle of all time. The manger could not be more unfriendly and the staff reflects the poor management. Simple requests are almost always denied and the portions look to be made for small children. Steer clear of this location

I go back to this chipotle, they put lettuce on burrito without me asking. I say no lettuce, she picks off a few pieces then rolls it. Manager sees, looks at me and says "for here or to go?" Fuck you, mane.

This place is one of the worst Chipotle locations in terms of customer service. The workers here are arrogant. I usually ask for extra cheese on my tacos. The typical response are eyes rolled at me while the server adds a small pinch of cheese. When I ask for a little more, I am met with a sigh and sometimes another pinch of cheese. This happens with such regularity that I often get nervous and dread having to ask for extras on my food when coming to this location. Listen up workers, why do you care how much cheese I want in MY tacos??  Does it cost you money to put more? No. Does it create any significant added work for you?? No. Does it impede the already snail pace of the customer line?  No. I'm the paying customer so if I'd like more cheese or beans or whatever in my food, unless there is a rule against it, you should oblige.
There's some some serious portion control going on up in hurr. My request for extra vegetables was blatantly ignored.

I go to this Chipotle at least once a week. Usually I can overlook the lackluster service because of the awesome food! Things have definitely gone downhill since my last review. Apparently I'm not the only one that thinks that the meat portions are skimpy because the three people in front of me all asked for a little more meat. The response they got was two more cubes/pieces of meat and a snarky "any more meat and you'll get charged for double meats." Okay, I get it, you have portions... but when I checkout and see that the ENTIRE upstairs is closed (including the bathroom) to customers, I've had it. Sure, I get it if you want to clean up there 10-15 minutes before close... but this was AN HOUR AND A HALF before your closing time. At one point I counted TEN customers standing or sitting on the weird S-shaped bench because there was not enough seating. If you don't care if I have a place to sit and eat the food I paid for, I don't need to be back. Goodbye Chipotle Tuesdays.

I don't know why anyone would go to any Chipotle (especially during the lunch rush) if they value their ears and vocal chords.  Almost every Chipotle has this problem, but this one is particularly bad.
Muy bueno.
This location shorted me on the bowl, now I will never return.

Every time I go here it isn't crowded. The staff is decent, not friendly, but not rude. I found that my steak was lacking your typical chipotle seasoning last week, but other than that not a bad location.
I haven't written a YELP review in 3 years. However, this chipotle is not good. The portions are smaller and not what I expect. WACK
My go-to spot for lunch in the financial district during work.
These guys are working their butts off.
A-ok!  Fast and friendly service, clean, good location - can't ask for much more!

I got catering (the Big Spread) for 20 people for my birthday on a Saturday and cant say enough good things about this place. The food quality, service and everything was perfect. Chris (the manager) was awesome and really dedicated to his clients. I never write a review in Yelp but I thought this one was really worth it. Thanks so much 211 Sutter St Chipotle !

I've come during lunch time and they are very fast. Amazingly fast. Everybody already knows if they like Chipotle or not, but I just want to let you know that even if the line looks really long, you can get through it and still have time to eat your lunch.

I'm normally not the type of person to write a review, as I have to moderate restaurant reviews on another website.  When I do write a review, it's because the restaurant has either spectacularly impressed me, or they have failed in some manner, which I feel needs to be addressed.  This is the latter kind of review.
I'm a big fan of the Chipotle franchise normally, and often crave their menu. Last night however was an eye opening experience.

I have been to this particular Chipotle twice, two annual conferences in a row. It's fairly fast, fairly inexpensive, fairly clean and predictable. It's also fairly crowded, fairly full of confused tourists (did the woman behind me really ask her husband "how does this work"), and fairly unhelpful (no they will not cut the burrito in half, but there's plastic knives over there). If I'm around next year, I might return. Or maybe I'll finally dive into something new - udon across the street perhaps, or cheesecake factory with a view. p.s. SECOND FLOOR?! OMG.

Sometimes I think to myself about how exactly does someone rate a fast food place, it's pretty much the same food everywhere.  I'm basically gonna skip over how I will always come back to Chipotle despite that it's not real Mexican food.
Got a giggle when I saw the price range on this yelp page, "$$$$", haha, someone must have had a bad experience.
I really love Chipotle! i go and eat chicken bowl twice a week.

I remember when Chipotle first opened up in S.F. I was so excited because I love Mexican food. I used to go to Chipotle almost every Friday for lunch. I noticed that when the chain first opened up, they were pretty generous with their portions. I used to always get the burrito bowl. But now, they are skimping Big time! Everytime I go there, especially the location on Sutter st., they don't pile on the food like they used to. I know the economy is going through tough times, but Come On!!! If I'm going to be spending $10.00+ on a burrito bowl, I want to be full.

This is probably the fastest Chipotle I've been to. Even during the times when the lines are almost out the door, the lines gets down pretty fast. Workers are friendly and super fast at prepping my food. One of my go to places for lunch!
I only recently tried Chipotle and love the burritos to I'm a big fan.  This location needs to do something about the noise level and inability to communicate with the servers.

Woohoo! This location is relatively new (opened earlier in 2013), but since it's in FiDi, it's PACKED during the lunch hours. They tried to create a line barrier with cushioned seats, but the line is still too long for it, haha.

This location is regularly stingy with the meat. Today was the last time they charge me $7 bucks for two tablespoons of barbacoa. This seems to be a company wide policy but I will try getting my chipotle fix from the 525 Market St location.
Let me start with: I love Chipotle. I always get a steak burrrito bowl with a tortilla on the side. Its my go to for a quick lunch.
Decent service, fresh salads. But if you have to use the restroom, don't throw your recipe away. There's a code for the upstairs potty on your recipe. Ha!
Chipotle was definitely on point today!

people sure hype chipotle a lot, but i'd never tried it. i tried to have an open mind going in, but i just didn't like it that much. it was pretty bland and it's disappointing that the pinto beans have bacon in them. i really wish the downtown area could get a good mexican restaurant, but i still haven't found one.

The rare 2 story burrito place! This is in between FiDi, ChinaTown, French Bistros, Irish Bars, and Fancy shopping. The place is surrounded by glass and window seats, with an upstairs mezzanine. So you can watch people while you wolf down a 2 pound burrito, or they can watch you with hungry  eyes as they pass by.
Really Chipotle?  Every other Chipotle has given me extra beans instead of rice except you. Seriously downhill from your early days. Never going to this one again. They've become huge cheapskates.
So far the best Chipotle compared to other three locations in downtown area.

Same menu and quality as other chipotles. However I definitely think it's better than the o'farrel one, which doesn't taste as fresh to me. I'm a big fan of the burrito bowls which save me some calories, but are still very filling. I usually get carnitas and steak. Today I tried the sofritas. I was expecting cubes of tofu, but it was actually strips. It was very flavorful, but overall I didn't enjoy it very much and it didn't seem very healthy due to all the seasoning. It's a great option for vegetarians but if you eat meat you probably won't prefer it to the other selections.

I have been a Chipotle enthusiast ever since my first burrito back in high school. Back in the day I used to go on Chipotle runs with my friends after I already ate dinner, I was a little obsessed. Of the countless times I had Chipotle I have only been disappointed a small amount that can still be counted on one hand.

Burrito with black beans, fresh veggies, sofrito, cheese, salsa, guacamole for $2.00 more. A $10 burrito. They are pretty stingy on the cheese. I didn't find the burrito to be very exciting and can't see going back. There are too many other less antiseptic places in the neighborhood for the same price.
the new tofu option called sofritas is made with hodo soy and is delicious!!!  very nice.
Stopped by Chipotle on the way home from work - this was my very first time at any Chipotle ( again, proving I'm slow on the uptake )
EDIT: I made a complaint on
Great food, best prices.  I get breakfast AND lunch in here for under $10 a day, which is unheard of in the financial district.  Always a smile from the employees.  Keep up the great work!

I ordered a tuna melt from their menu and they tried to charge me extra for cheese.  Shady, shady.  Sorry, but a tuna melt is not a tuna melt without cheese.  Until they change this practice, I'll have to give them 1 star.  I'll stick to the better deli at Rincon Market.

UNSANITARY!! The cashier was counting change on the cutting board!! I didn't even notice because I was looking at the menu on the wall as I placed my order. Can't imagine where those coins have been in the financial district.. The lady preparing my sandwich didn't even wear gloves! Where's a health inspector when you need one?!
This little deli is hidden and convenient for those of us searching for a quick bite at lunchtime... Especially in Soma when 10k employees empty into the streets at that same time.

Nice place to get affordable food. I have no problem with the quality of the food like other reviewers. Quick service when I go there. Small little hole in the wall spot. Ihey have no indoor seating everything is togo.  There is some really nice outdoor seating around the corner in the courtyard
$3.50 for the breakfast burrito.
While very affordable, the food here was not very tasty.  I got a breakfast burrito and a pb&j.
BIG sandwiches, cheapest place I know of in the entire downtown which is great on my budget and the sandwiches are actually good too.

This place is a hidden little gem in SOMA.  It's always the same 2-3 people working there, so it has a very family-ish atmosphere, and they're very friendly.  There's no seating inside, but just outside is a pretty public area with fountains and benches and tables around the corner.

Really nice people, but bad food. I ordered the breakfast burrito without salsa. What got was a MICROWAVED potato wrap with barely any eggs & some cheese. Not worth it, threw it away & went to Specialtys. Seriously bad, nuked eggs! WTF?

Hole in the wall place?  Check.  Greasy breakfast burrito that will put you in a food coma?  Check.  This has got to be the cheapest place in SF where you can get a HUMUNGOUS sausage breakfast burrito for only $4!  Definitely not for those who want to eat healthier; they basically microwave the sausage and potatoes, but it's good once in a while for a "cheat" day.

Um, I can't believe how cheap the sandwiches are here. I got a PB&J for $2. Yeah, it's just peanut butter and jam on wheat bread, but honestly, I've never seen a sandwich cheaper than $6 in the FiDi. They also have what appears to be a really extensive menu. I'll be back!
Stopped by last week and this week to pick up my usual lox bagel and noticed that they've raised their prices. Lox Bagel is now $3.50.
Get the special, bagel w/ cream cheese, lox and the usual trimmings for $3.50!

There's something to be said for the no-frills experience of City Kinetics. Their sandwiches and salads are simple, with nary a leaf of frisée or pomegranate relish to jazz it up. On the other hand, what they do offer is fresh, made to order, and much cheaper than everything nearby.  Many of the people who come here are so familiar with the menu that they don't even glance up at it as they order. While I was waiting in line, one customer began to specify how she wanted her sandwich only to have the person making it respond: "don't worry, I know how you like it."
Come here every morning for the lox bagel... $3!!! Where else in the city can you find that? The owner is always there and is super friendly, gonna try the tamales today!

Cheap sandwiches- great service. Cheap food in SOMA? Wow, awesome. They are perfect for lunch. They have the best egg salad and its super yummy. The women there make it fast and the price is unbeatable. Less than $3 for an egg salad. Cant beat that!
It didn't make me sick, so that's a good sign. I don't know why I don't just give it two stars, that's all it really deserves.
They have a sign on Mission Street advertising $5.99 for one or two years now.  I get their sandwich, one bag of chip and 12 oz soda.  They have always charged me $6.00.

Was in search of a smoothie place since Jamba Juice shut down. Found this place, ordered a strawberry banana smoothie and was greeted by the nicest man in all of San Francisco. The smoothie is delicious and exactly what I was looking for.
I'm not sure how this place has so many stars, it's not a really bad place, but it's pretty ghetto haha, and there's definitely better options.
Stopped in for a breakfast burrito. Fine burrito, excellent, friendly service. What's not to love?
