Eww I will not going back. Surprisingly in the 4 years I have been working in the area and the number of times I have passed by this place I have never been tempted to go in and I never will be again.

Dude gave my friend a free cookie.  Great service.  Where else can you get a roast beef downtown for $4.75 out the door.  Bfast menu looked on point $3.50 bfast buritto.  The owner obviously take alot of pride in what he does and takes credit card.
two stars for how nice the guy is who owns it.....stand up guy and always pleasant.

Food is a solid good. Prices are REALLY good for downtown SF, although technically in the SOMA. I have had one of their rbeakfast sandwhichs and it was quite nummy. I tried their tri-tip sandwhich and it was "ok" - I have had better, but for $5, I am not going to complain.

Workers a really sweet, the guy is super flirtatious and can make even the hardest women smile on a Monday morning!  You can't beat the prices at this small hole in the wall.  I always order breakfast burritos, no meat for $3.
I stopped in to get break, and to my surprise, the staff was very much into providing great service.  We were all greeted with an enthusiastic smile that seemed to permeate the walls and floors.

This is a good place to get a sandwich, chips and can of soda for $6. However, customer service depends on who you get to serve you. The owner and the thin lady are nice and competent, but the not-so-thin lady is sort of rude, doesn't listen well, and acts like she doesn't want to be there.

This place is clutch.  It's hard spending twice as much for a sandwich at Working Girl when you have City Kinetics pretty much next door.  They're sandwiches aren't inventive, but that's not the point.  And very friendly service.
Weird name for a place.
Super friendly owner and fairly priced food for good quality!
I love ordering smoothies there due to good drinks and good prices. But the lady inside doesn't like to make smoothies for me.

so... lets start off by saying, when i think of getting brekfast from a cafe in the financial district, a bagel sandwhich porbably will cost me around $5! Here at kinetics, you can buy almost anything on the menu for less than $5!! Even a gyro or a tamale! The customer service is amzaing, and the staff is very welcoming.
"You're a good man."

You cannot beat this place for the price. The burrito was under $4, and by far the HEAVIEST breakfast burrito I have had in this area. It's literally TWICE the size of seller's market breakfast burrito!

I ordered a smoothie. It tasted like bubble gum. Gross. Fresh orange juice NOT. The lady put Sunny Delight and she must have put bubble gum flavored sherbert too. I took one sip and ended up giving it to a homeless woman.
Good value for the FiDi area.  No line at lunch. It's a little hard to find.
You could bludgeon somebody to death with the dense breakfast burrito I ordered here this morning, and at 4 bucks for a sausage breakfast burrito, that's one cheap murder weapon right there!

Makes me want to move to San Francisco without a job & get drunk every night.  That way I would need a really cheap hangover cure that was enough calories to last me the entire day on my nonexistent budget until I went out again that night.  A City Kinetics breakfast burrito would be all that & more.  Cheesy, starchy, eggy, hearty, booze sopping goodness. For $3!
Solid, quick sandwiches and friendly service. This place feeds my bagel sandwich fix for less than $7 and without a line.

How are the Vietnamese sandwiches so cheap?? Under $5 for a sandwich with the works: toasted bun, BBQ pork, pickled vegetables, cilantro, jalapeños. And they are *not* shy with the jalapeños. Since my family is from Szechuan (the mouth-numbing spice capital of China), I like to pride myself on my ability to handle spicy food. But even I think these peppers are intense! Be prepared to lose feeling on your tongue or shed a few tears. If you choose to remove the peppers from your sandwich before you eat it, no shame. You'll probably still get a slight numbing taste -- that's how strong these peppers are.

I had some of the weirdest coffee of my life at this place.  One day my friend and  I were like "We've been going to the same coffee places over and over again, why not branch out?"  Tart to Tart was the first place we tried and after a few sips we decided to stick to the beaten path again for a while.

Got donut holes, banana boba drink, and Vietnamese sandwich.  Donut holes were good, a bit over sized, but they're donut holes...not the cakey kind, but the yeast risen ones.  Extra yum.  The boba drink was mediocre. Drink itself tasted bland.  The bobas were hard and tasteless. The sandwich was decent, not the best and not the worse I've had.  The bread was warm and tasted great.  The meat was okay.  The carrots weren't as pickled as I'd like.  Good amount of spicy jalopenos and just the right amount of cilantro and paste.
I can only speak to the quality of their vietnamese sandwiches, as I haven't had the opportunity to order pastries or drinks.
The vietnamese sandwich is really good. I got the veggie sandwich two days in a row. To top if off its onlt $4.5.
This is my go-to place for coffee. Yes SBUX is right next door, but seriously TTT's coffee is so well priced and excellent quality.
The place has awesome Vietnamese sandwiches. There is also a handful of croissants and other pastries to choose from.
You wouldn't think so but their combination bahn mi is surprisingly delicious! And also under $8!
I picked up a chocolate scone this morning on my way to work. It was around $2.15ish and it looked appetizing. But after you eat it, it tasted rather dry.
CLARIFICATION:
Looks like a coffee shop, runs like a deli. Every time I come here it's for their banh mi. That stuff is legit.

Don't be fooled by how scrumptious the chocolate dipped peanut butter cookies in a jar appear to be!  Those cookies looked so good to me that I had to walk back to get one.  I'd passed the first time because it was breakfast time and I felt inappropriate.  Later, I couldn't resist.  They kept calling me!  When I finally got it though, I discovered that the cookie was hard and lacked, of all things, peanut butter!  The taste was flat.  I didn't even bother to finish the whole cookie.

this place gave me food poisoning! I guess I should have known not to buy anything from a place that sells ice cream donuts and Vietnamese sandwiches however I was in a hurry and needed something quick and I love viet sandwiches! I had the BBQ chicken and it was just OKAY! it wasn't worth getting food poisoning that lasted 5 days! I will not be returning! the service was friendly maybe it was because no one was in there but I give it 2 stars for that.

This is one of my breakfast pastry stops in SOMA, since it's on the way to the office from the Montgomery Street BART Station.  I like their Chocolate and Apple Muffins.  They are always moist and fresh.  They also do a nice job with their Scones and turnovers too.  I know they also do a nice job with their Vietnamese Iced Coffee drinks.  Our office has ordered cakes from them that are also really good.  I know there are other options, but it's definitely worth a try if you're in the area.

as many folks have said, this place is never crowded... that's because there are a dozen places nearby by with better coffee, pastries and service than tart to tart. their coffee is on par with the 7-11 next door, the refrigerated drinks are more expensive than walgreens across the street, and their pastries don't hold a candle to specialties or the sentinel -- both within 300 feet.
Sandwiches are expensive here especially the Vietnamese sandwiches! $5 for such a small sandwich. I'm not impressed! But the sandwiches were alright.
You got to love a pastry/Vietnamese sandwich spot whose name is a cute take-off on a cheesy 80s TV show starring Robert Wagner.
dropped in on a sunday talking on a cellphone. wasn't serviced right away. one other person in line.

Love this place. Employees extremely friendly, coffee is really good! And the pastries are good. I love the chocolate croissants. Price is also very reasonable. I look forward to coming back. I prefer this place over the major name coffee shops around the corner I do not want to mention!
As promised, I came back for the salad and pasties, but was disappointed by both. The salad had all of four ingredients; the pasty was soggy from the microwave.
Not good. The pecan pie was too sweet (I don't usually say that) and the crust was super hard and inedible.

I've only had the sandwiches here and they're pretty darn good. The other places in the Financial District aren't good and compare similarly in prices. This is a great spot to pick up a quick sandwich, but it's not a destination spot. The staff is very friendly as well and they remember my orders :)

I was visiting San Francisco and wanted to grab some bubble tea. This place fit the bill. While they do have bubble tea, their menu doesn't list the price, and they don't actually  have all the favors they have posted. Once I found a flavor I wanted that they had, it was good. I also got a sandwich, which was good but very standard fare. The place is clean, though generic, boarding on tacky (strands of Christmas lights in February). With all the other choices around, it's hard to justify coming back here.

Their desserts look very appealing at least until I tasted them.  The ones I tasted all have the same flaw, overly sweetened for my palate, which just kills the desire for me to want any more of their overly sweetened desserts, which is unfortunate.
Time: 1:38pm/64°F sunny

I first popped into this little bakery because of sheer convenience. Located on the corner of New Montgomery & Mission, it is in the direct walking path between my office and the BART station. I pass a handful of places that could offer a quick bite, however, Tart to Tart hardly ever has a line, and service is much, MUCH quicker.

I came to tart to tart for a bahn mi - probably the worst decision I made that week. I should have known by their name that they are probably best known for their sweets and pastries. But I thought since they had a picture of bahn mi posted on their windows, that it might be a specialty. Nope!

A bahn mi + boba cafe (disguised as a bakery) literally right downstairs from my office?? This can be dangerous for me. The sandwiches are a tiny bit more pricey than my favorite bahn mi place in Oakland (Cam Huong), but you're still paying less than $5 for a sandwich and that is a total steal in the FiDi area. I also approve of its proximity to my work for a quick to-go lunch.

Black Forest tart... Not bad at all since Black Forest cakes are pretty hard to find in SF. Nice cafe for hanging out and having a little something sweet along with it. Similar to the sunset location, they have sweets and decent coffee. A good place to try for sure aside from big chained coffee places.

The only thing I've tried here is the bahn mi (Vietnamese sandwiches) and of that only the vegetarian.  It's hard to go wrong with pickled vegetables, cilantro, and jalapeños, and this place satisfies.  Unfortunately like most bahn mi places, 1 is not enough and 2 is a bit too much.  First world problems I know.  The baguette is crunchy and reasonably fresh, the ingredients are tasty, and best of all there's hardly any line even during lunch hours.  Prices are good for San Francisco.
Pretty good bubble tea...in SoMa? Count me in!

Got a egg and bacon sandwich but there was nothing special about it. Service was OK. Appreciated the 10% student discount and how quiet the cafe was on a Friday morning. Tried something new but  there's nothing here that will bring me back.

probably more 2.5. i was looking at the green tea ice cream but it looked old so asked for a taste. The lady proceeded to give me the top which of course tasted nasty. I opted for the green tea bubble tea with almond milk. Bubbles were nice consistency and like that they blend it. not the typical bubble tea place but ok

They have decent boba for being in the financial district. Its probably the only boba place I've found in this area so far. Their desserts are good but its located in an area where there are plenty of better options to chose from should you want dessert. Their prices for Vietnamese sandwiches are cheap as its less than $5 and they are super good. I've never had their other sandwiches or salads aside from the Vietnamese sandwich.
Raisin Bran muffin looked tasty but it was super dry.

The secret here is their Vietnamese sandwiches (banh mi) are very good. I used to drive all the way down to San Jose to get a fix and now I can stay in the city. The place totally didn't look like it would have authentic Vietnamese sandwiches but I was told the owner was Vietnamese so there you have it. My husband and I have been going at least once a week. I like their special or dac biet and he likes the BBQ pork. The donut holes are also really good.
Lovely staff! Very friendly, efficient, and helpful. Even when they are busy I feel as if I am attentively taken care of.

The service is pretty prompt (and never busy) and I come here often since I work right across the street. Their pastries are very average, although they make up for it in sheer size. I generally go for the blueberry muffin, and the texture makes me think it's whole wheat (or am I just deluding myself?).

As others have written, this is probably the best Banh Mi you can get for the price (under $5) in the area. While I grew up eating Lee's Sandwiches and their sub-$3 Banh Mi, this is a pretty great alternative.

Went here today for a quick lunch ..... Service and staff is super nice but I didn't come here for good service I came here for a quick lunch and it was just awful me and my body order lamb shawarma but we got lamb in burrito rap not good at all when I tried it I want to ask them why in world would you do that to shawarma also asked if they have eggplant they were out but did offer hummus not my choice...... Please owners if you will read my review fix it you will have better reviews and of cause more business but for now you only get one star for food and 5 star for service...... Avg 2.5 star.
This place is so disgusting. I just bought 2 hard boiled eggs and had to throw them away because the egg whites were so rotten they had the texture of ricotta cheese when I cracked them open.

I haven't tried anything besides their bagels (ONLY $2 W/ CREAM CHEESE BTW) but the two people working are so nice! Wonderful customer service! A bagel for $2 around the financial district sounds unreal but it's sold right here!
What you want for five bucks in The Financial District
The one time I decided to come try this place was my last. The old couple there is super friendly and funny but I can't just give them my money without good food in return!

I have never thrown away lunch after 2 bites but I did today.  To watch my other co-workers do the same says a lot. 1 star is way generous...They microwaved the meat for the Gyro's and the Sharwma....nasty lettuce and flour tortilla as the wrap...its was nasty in bite one and full on lost urge to eat on second bite.

Have only ever been here for breakfast but the woman who works here is kind and friendly, you can pretty much order any kind of breakfast sandwich you can think of and it's very well priced for the financial district. Large beverage and snack selection too.

If you aren't paying attention you could walk right past this place! One of the first spots I went for breakfast when I started working in financial district because it looked like a quick choice. It's family owner (which you have to appreciate) and the food isn't expensive. It's good for breakfast or even a quick lunch if you're looking for a pick up. Although they so have seats it's a small establishment with few tables. Id definitely come here to read a book and eat a sandwich.
The first time that I have ever thrown a lunch that I paid for into the garbage.

The old lady running this place is bat-sh!t crazy!!! I was perusing my options & looking at Yelp reviews, & she proceeds to think I'm up to no good for whatever paranoid reason because I wasn't ordering right away. She loudly says, "If you don't buy, you can't look!"

We ate here on the run to an appointment we had, the place is small, attached to some business building (no bathrooms FYI), the cooks were super nice, so was the guy ringing us up (maybe a family operation), but the food was sooooo reheated frozen.. oh man it was bad. I got the falafel pita sandwich, the wife had the crab cake sandwich, I hate frozen site bought stuff, I could've bought it and made it myself for cheaper... I was disappointed, I see little restaurants like this and really want to be wowed, and this was just not it... Family seemed nice, food was not...

Affordable, quick and delicious Mediterranean food. I had the gyro melt. Gyro meat on a garlic bread roll with melted cheddar cheese, lettuce, onion, tomatoes and pickles. I highly recommend it. Another lady had the spicy shawarma which looked and smelled as good as my sandwich did. I will definitely be back and will bring some friends along.

This is my go-to lunch spot. Quick and easy with good food and friendly service. I typically go for their $5.99 lunch special falafel plate. I'd never really been a fan of falafel before I tried it here and now I CRAVE IT. I think the only qualm I could have about this place is that it's pretty small so it fills up fast. I might not get a seat if I was planning on eating in. Still, the service is fast and the food always hits the spot.
I am giving them two stars because they couple running the stop was nice...although the woman was very stressed even though there were 3 people in line.

Always have your phone with you! At all times, at all costs! If you leave it at home or at the office, it is useless to you and you can only blame yourself if you can't Yelp a restaurant in advance. (Man, I'm starting to sound like my parents)
I walk by this place every day on my way to work; so I thought why not pick up some food to go for lunch.  BIG MISTAKE

Ordered the falafel on pita, super delicious.  It wasn't too spicy, full of falafel instead of fillers and other ingredients.  Not my got place for lunch, or even falafel, but a great alternative if you are looking to mix things up.

I have reviewed this place before, but couldn't seem to edit my past review, so I am writing another one. Last time I went here I just ordered dolma's, which were yummy. This time I ordered the lunch special. This had a couple dolma's in it, some hummus, pita bread, and tabbouleh. I would say the pita and the hummus was decent, but not too excited about it. I would recommend the tabbouleh-that was delicious! I still recommend the dolma's as well, of course.
There were these neon lights and hand-made signs on the front, and people wading inside, so I decided to enter Fida's where I got the gyro sandwich and a bottle of water.
Love this place!

Everything seems fine until you notice that the gyro just went up a dollar while you were waiting for it (they don't bother explaining that the wrap adds a buck).  Once my gyro arrived things got worse.  If you like spending $7 for a veggie wrap that was supposed to be a gyro, then you'll love this place.  I was able to find three small pieces of meat so I suppose that technically it wasn't a veggie wrap. Also, I asked for spicy and it was as bland as could be. All for $7!

I always get the same thing for breakfast - the pita sandwich. Good value and consistent! I tried the falafels and hummus for lunch but was not impressed. I would pass for lunch but this will still be my go to place for breakfast!
Daily special for 4.99 that includes a crab salad sandwich, chips, and bottle of water? Wait a minute, we're in the FIDI right? SCORE!! At least that's what I thought.

I wandered out of the office today hungry and looking for lunch with no real destination. A few blocks down California I found Fida's tucked into a lobby of a large office building. There were a few people in line so without Yelping I crossed myself at the door and decided to take a chance. (Just kidding, I'm Jewish)
Family owned place.  I like it, the mom who makes the food has spunk.  Everything I've tried there is good.  Gyros, egg salad sandwich... and my morning english muffin w/ bacon egg n cheese!
I always got the greek platter or the chicken wrap... Always satisfying.
The people here are very nice.  But the food is not every good.

I really wanted to love this place but it was just missing the pizaz in their sandwiches. I ordered the gyro melt. The lady was nice but the sandwich was just not there. The pattie lacked a lot of flavor. However, their clam chowder is yummy. I'd go back only for the chowder.
Cute place with comfortable environment. Just had a breakfast burrito and coffee, and both were good.
The best part of this establishment is the friendly service that you receive.  The food is a little disappointing, however.

I love this place for breakfast. The owners are VERY friendly.. I got an egg and cheese on a croissant. (It was HUGE) They make an egg sandwhich with REAL eggs, on a REAL skillet...not yellow liquid in a microwave. She adds salt and pepper the same way you would make it at home. I'm really happy with this place.

*Great* variety of food to choose from--mediteranean, italian, breakfast burritos and such, bagels and pastries, baklava, and on and on.  Small but clean, and very friendly service. I can't believe this place isn't overrun with customers yet!  Seem like a hidden secret of a place to me.
Three and half stars.
You might get distracted by the sandwiches. Don't. Mediterranean is their specialty. Wraps are where it's at.
The facts:

Meh.  Cheap sandwich, but small portions and not all that special.  I guess I should have known better to order an Italian sub in a Mediterranean place, because I think it had bologna on it and waaaay too much red onion.  Next time, I'll stick to what they do well.

ICK~DO NOT EAT HERE!  I've seen them mix leftovers (who knows how old) with new batches.  Not only that, but they have served expired products to friends that have (mistakenly) gone there for a quick bite, only to wind up taking just that and throwing the rest in the garbage.

So, within a 3-4 block radius, I've tried most of the Mediterranean places.  My biggest gripe w/ most of these places is how they build their sandwiches:  pita vs lavash, grilled not grilled (and to what extent), sloppiness vs cleanliness.

I go to Fida's for lunch about twice a month. The service is personable and friendly, and I enjoy sitting at a table to eat. Large selection of drinks and snacks (chips, cookies, fruit). The food is fine; I enjoy the lasagna with a side salad because it's filling. I also like the crab-cake sandwich. The consistency in quality and service is a plus.

I came here earlier in the week by recommendation. Someone told me that they ate here pretty often, so I figured, "What the hey?" Now, my experience here could be a bit biased, as I had falafel a few days before at a place rated as the top restaurant in my city. It was great, and the hummus tasted like mashed potatoes.
As the quick grab-and-go burrito joint serving office workers in the 2nd and Market corridor, Rico Mex is a Mexican lunchtime joint tucked away in a little alley between high-rises.
I don't understand all the negative reviews; this place is as awesome as it is authentic and it's a nice alternative to the neighboring Mexican restaurants in SoMa.

I went here once during the lunch rush, and it was hectic and the food tasted not well prepared. I went back another day after the lunch rush, and the place still had an air of sloppiness about it. The ordering process is confusing, with a menu posted like an eye exam from the place where you make the order. The food, when only one or two other patrons are there still feels rushed and bland. And when they add chips to it, it's literally 6 chips(they do sell a bag for 50 cents). Is that a weird sampler?

I stop by this spot from time to time for a breakfast burrito on my way into work. The chorizo and eggs is pretty skimpy on the chorizo. I generally get the bacon and eggs and pay for extra bacon. They also hit you on the extra charges for stuff like rice, cheese, sour cream, guacamole, so if you like all the fixings, it'll add up.

I ordered a burrito cornado part of their special.  They messed up my order and gave me a super burrito instead.  Charged me 3 dollars more.  Top of that, it tasted old and bland, never again will I come back here.

Had the vege-breakfast burrito.  I really enjoy egg dishes, and it is hard to go wrong by me with breakfast foods, but somehow, they made the breakfast burrito taste yuckky.  It tasted like the eggs and vegetables were boiled.  I saw the woman make the eggs in a ratty skillet, so I know it wasn't boiled, but yuk - it was tasteless.  Not going back.  Plus my stomach started bubbling after I ate.  Not good.

I don't think I've ever walked out of an establishment before. Like many others, I work near by. I've had a carne asada burrito from here for lunch a while back. Meh, I've had better, but I've heard raving reviews about their breakfast burritos so of course I'd give it a second chance. Unfortunately, the two people who worked the morning decided to concentrate on a to-go order? when there were 3 people standing in line. I can tell they were growing as restless as I was. I didn't get acknowledged for about 6 minutes  -- They also charge for everything under the sun. A dollar for cheese... really? For a sprinkle of cheese? No thanks. What a joke. You want to help out the mom and pop stores, but you're better off going to Chipotle.

I had a super burrito with carne asada, and I think I got what I expected for the price (about $8). The one frustrating part about this business is that they don't have a menu that you can see (or at least that I could see) when I walked in. I read other people's reviews saying that the burritos were $5-6, but when she asked me what I wanted on the burrito aside from meat, I said everything. Typically, if they charge extra for guacamole, they tell you that it's extra, but I'm guessing that's what happened here.

Okay, I think my three star rating is slightly preemptive, in that the first time I ate at Rico Mex, I can't remember, and the second time I opted for a no cheese burrito  since it's an extra dollar for cheese and I only had a five dolla bill (what?! Yes, never again).
Yeah, it's cheap, though not super high quality.

I ordered the al pastor regular burrito with sour cream. It was so bad I stopped eating it, threw it away and went and bought myself lunch again. I'm not sure there are words to appropriately describe the crap that is this burrito. If you're around the area and looking for quick mexican, try Tacos San Buena on Sansome at Bush.
Best basic Mexican food in the FiDi. Prices are also decent considering the location. Out the door lines during lunch hour so come early.
Great burritos off the beaten path in SOMA. They have a really tasty El Pastor, if you like spicy pork.
I'm a huge burritos fan. Come here perhaps 1-2x per month for the past 10 years. Burritos were ok, not the best and definitely not the worst. That is until yesterday.
Great food, price, and service. The lady that works there is too nice!
Its just OK. Had a burrito.  The chicken was a little sketch.

let me preface this review by saying it is VERY hard for me to distinguish a Mexican restaurant as great, or better than average since most of the time it's always the same ingredients presented differently.
Wow $3.70 for a breakfast burrito! I still prefer the taste and quality at front deli, despite it being $1 more.

It is ok.   I come often because it is right behind my office BUT that is not because I like it.  Burritos are pretty sub standard compared to what I get at home in LA.   I've also come for breakfast a few times.  Run by a husband and wife who are pretty friendly. On the bright side, it is not expensive compared to the hipster food in the surrounding area.
first off I love burritos. there are definitely good and bad ones, and this place was on the bad side.

I'm a regular here - mostly for their breakfast burritos, which are my go-to Fat-Free-Friday/hangover cure. It's just the right size not to put one into a coma, and I love their fresh salsa - especially the green stuff which I wish they would sell in bottles as I'd put it on everything.
I get a basic burrito: beans, rice, cheese and avocado & it's 200% better than anything at Chipoltle! Their chips could be better.
Ordered a regular chicken burrito, came out to be about $6 something.

Come here in the mornings for their breakfast burritos. A good option if you want hot food but not McDonalds in the area. The burritos are a good size and you get to pick what you want in your burrito. They make it in front of you. One one negative thing is that the lady can take a long time. So if you don't have 15 minutes to spare, I suggest you look somewhere else.

Ordered a couple burritos from this place for the office for lunch. Very nice staff and the guy also threw in a couple of extra bags of tortilla chips just because I had to wait an extra 5 minutes for 9 burritos. Waiting wasn't a huge deal for me, so I thought it was a nice gesture. Food was good, way filling. Mexican food here does not compare to food back home (San Diego), but this place was not too bad.
Hands down, the best carnitas I have found in the FiDi.

There are quite a few mixed reviews on here...so I felt the need to try this place out for myself. I usually go to El Farro (bc screw Chipotle - yeah I said it) but they aren't anything to write home about.
The food was alright, but it's a clusterf*ck going in there during lunch hour.

The food is decent for the price. But its nothing special. I would much rather spend my money elsewhere, or spend more money to get a better meal. I ordered a burrito, which was decently sized, but not as big as one from a place like Chipotle. Actually, I paid the same price as a burrito with guacamole at Chipotle, and Chipotle tastes much better.
Rico Mex is GOOD!!!

My office is near Tropisueño so my doorman totally understood what I needed when I asked if he knew of a real Mexican place nearby.  He sent me to Rico Mex with instructions to get the Chili Relleno and a taco; I'm never one to turn those down.
Had this for delivery. Not a fan.
Tasty cheap eats, quick service. Accepts credit cards
I liked: soda in cans for a buck.

Probably the best Mexican restaurant within a several block radius of where I work (this place is much better than a nearby national chain of "Mexican food" that draws a huge line out the door every weekday lunch).  The food at Rico Mex is very flavorful, pretty authentic in flavor, and generous in portion size.  The prices are inexpensive compared to other establishments in the area.  Although the atmosphere is lacking a bit, the food and speedy service make up for it.  I usually get my food to go so the ambience doesn't matter all that much to me anyway.
This place sucks!
I consider myself a reasonable person &  there are certain things I expect out of the food service industry.
Solid cheap Mexican food
If you're looking for a burrito induced coma for the second half of your work day, look no further.  This is a solid choice for a a burrito, not much else to say.
please keep in mind before coming here that you will start to have the urge to go to sleep after having lunch from this establishment...or is it just me?
Jeff and Il Massimo are the best!
I met a group there for lunch and the entrees were all solid.

This is a spacious Italian café that just oozes a warm home-y feeling in their food and atmosphere.  They make their own homemade bagels and hummus which I HIGHLY recommend trying.  I almost order the veggie hummus on a jalapeno bagel every other day...it is SOOO good.  And I like how the hummus is without tahini.  It's usually loaded with garlic and herbs and just really tastes fresh.
I love the lasagna!! Generous portions and they give you a big square of meaty lasagna gooeyness...

Salad looked and tasted like it had been sitting out all morning. Thank you for my 2 croutons. Also the bag of chips were stale. Guess that's what I get for paying 5 bucks for lunch. Probably wont come back, they are very quick though I was in and out. Cute place to eat by the fireplace at. Eh
Super friendly and understanding with yummy fresh food!! Numerous of great experiences:

This place is sooo good for breakfast!  It is my favorite in the area.  I try to limit myself from getting breakfast there too often, as it is not cheap by any means, but always look forward to the mornings when I let myself get their breakfast bagel or oatmeal.
Amazing food! I regularly get their salads and soup for lunch. Love the Ahi tuna salad and Tuscan! You won't be disappointed.
It was such a quaint and welcoming atmosphere with a fireplace and couches around the fireplace for reading, eating, etc.. The food is also made their fresh (including their breads!).

We love this place!  Amazing coffee made the old Italian way selected by the owner.  I had a great cup of Americano.  Service was the best that we experienced on our trip to San Fran.  We were looking for a place with "toast" due to the SF toast movement.  They did not even advertise that they have amazing homemade bread for toast making.  I had a delicious egg white omelet with basil, tomato and avocado.  The owner even gave food to a person in need passing by.  She has a amazing place and takes pride in serving food.  The basket tray that our food was served in was a great touch.
Reminds me of Italy. Wonderful space, great food, the breakfast coffee and lunch casual Italian eatery I have been looking for the past 4 years.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE good panini sandwiches, and love these small, tucked-away places I'm finding as a newbie in SF.  There are signs for Il Massimo all along Washington Street, with free menu dispensers on each one, so you couldn't possibly miss it.  We stumbled upon it on a previous walk, and I decided to come back and try it for myself when I was really hungry.
Welcome to San Francisco a few decades rewinded! Can't help but feel nostalgic & old school as soon as I enter the place.
Perfect balance.
Disappointed in this place

This deli offers really yummy, upscale food in a deli environment. You almost can't go wrong with anything you order. My staff and I get our lunches here on almost a daily basis and we all love it. The staff are super friendly and nice and they make a point of remembering your name and preferences.

I usually don't write reviews on yelp, but after I digested this place's poor excuse for food, I thought I'd write about how horrible this place is.  I honestly don't think there's a difference in taste between the food and the paper bag they delivered it in.  I ordered the Mozzarella sandwich, and this was probably the worst and most tasteless mozzarella sandwich I ate in all my life: unusually high bread to ingredients ratio, a really dry sandwich, flavorless, and a horrible pass for a rustico bread.  To my knowledge, rustico bread should not be heavy crumbly whole wheat focaccia bread.  This was just a hodge podge of random ingredients slapped together - it probably would have been better to graze leaves out of a garden...

Il Massimo is a great place to stop by for lunch if you're looking for a quick fix.  Catering to the busy lives Financial District employees, they streamline the process of getting you in, getting you your choice meal, and getting you out.

Massimo's is another solid spot for lunch in the FiDi. They offer a good selection of paninis and salads that are either made-to-order or pre-made. They also have hot plates and offer various pasta dishes, chicken parmesan, etc. Everything is fresh and I love that they use fresh mozzarella!
Note to self and others:
TINGLES MY SENSES
good take out place. I am giving it 4 star because it has nice sandwiches to go. It's not something to crave for but a healthy fast lunch with good variety.
Good panini when you want one and the staff is pretty friendly. When you don't have time to run to a north beach deli and you want something healthier, it's a nice fix.
Loved the chicken panini!  Can't wait to eat the little italian cookies and the gelato!  Also looking forward to the lasagna and hot dishes.
Love it.  The salads, sides, sandwiches, and hot specials are so delicious.  It's like having an italian grandma cook for you 2 blocks from work.
I decided to give Massimo another chance, and used them to cater a recent lunch.  We were tired of our usual haunts, and since my co-workers love the place, I figured I'd surprise them.

College cafeteria for workers in the Financial District. Walk into this place and you will know exactly what I mean. It is convenient for food / coffee at any time breakfast, brunch, snack, lunch. They have sandwiches and fast hot food ready to go for people on the run. The menu changes everyday with various Italian dishes like eggplant parmesan, lasagnas, stews, etc. Since most of their food is pre-made and sitting on steamers, it probably is not as good as it can be and for fast food, you're still paying restaurant prices.
3/5 good light food.

I was craving lasagna today for lunch. And, of course, I got on Yelp to find something good. I ordered their meat lasagna lunch combo with cucumber and tomato salad.  I was looking for a really meaty and cheezy lasagna. Their meat lasagna was decent and a bit more tamed then what I was hoping for. I'd give it a: 3.5/5.  The cucumber and tomato salad was delicious: 4/5.  Overall. 3.5/5

I went here on a Tuesday to try out their Chicken Parmesean.  I thought it was ok, but definitely tasted as if it were sitting there for awhile as the chicken was pretty dry and the breading was mush.  The noodles weren't drained and were very watery.  I want to try their panini's next time as the lady sitting next to me looked like she was having a blast with it.  Not sure if I'd recommend the food as of yet, but I will be back.
Massimo is a dependable lunch spot if you're looking for paninis, soups, and salads but don't forget to check out the daily hot food specials if you want something more substantial.

Meh.  Lunch was fine.  I got there around 12, got into a line of 4 or 5 people, and looked at my options in the display case.  Tons of sandwiches, a few salads, none particularly exciting.  I ended up going with the lentil arugula salad with tomatoes in a viniagrette and a bowl of white bean soup.  The lentil salad was passable.  Nice texture, decent flavor, but nothing to write home about.  The soup was bland bland bland.  And it had a weird floaty filmy texturey thing in it.  I'm not sure how to explain it other than that.  It stirred away when I made an effort, and then I tried not to think about it too much.  I don't think I'll be back.  It was bo-ring.  And a little weird.

Massimo is a decent place to grab a bite to eat with your coworkers if you happen to be in the Financial District.  I would never go out of my way to eat here, but the panini sandwiches and salads are pretty good, as are the hot food items like lasagna and chicken parmesan.  There are always tables here, so you will not be standing around too long.  This location has no windows, however, so the people watching options are slim to nil.  Their other location across Market Street from One Market has outdoor seating, which is nice on a warm day.

When I order catering for our office in-house meetings, I order what I like, what I eat and make sure to provide options just in case you don't. But who doesn't like Italian Pannini Sandwiches, fresh salads and Italian desserts?

they always have a great selection, and are pretty accommodating for special requests and such. Love the fresh parmesan that they have at the counter - i can heap ridiculous amounts of it on my salads. not the best bargain, but a great place to sit down for a healthy lunch.
A little pricey, but I love the Crudo panini that they offer.
I've stopped patronizing this place, after having a few bad experiences with their lentil salad and prosciutto sandwiches.  Some of my orders turned out to be a bit too greasy for me.

I LOVE this place. I come here maybe 3 or 4 days a week, and haven't gotten tired of it yet (this love affair has been going on for 3 weeks now). I love the sweet owners, husband and wife Jeff and Elena, and I love the food. They bake their own bread, and make their soups from scratch. I LOVE the fresh mozzarella sandwiches. They put it on a bread that I thought was foccaccia (which I normally hate). They call it "Rustica." Whatever it is, when they put it on their panini machine and that bread gets those awesome crispy toasted ridges, I'm in heaven. Especially since they put wild arugula in the mozzarella sandwich. I'm not a vegetarian and I like their other sandwiches (crudo, pastrami, steak and peppers, chicken salad, etc.), but their mozzarella-on-rustica sandwiches are THE BOMB. The also have other stuff too, like lasagna and salmon and whatnot (their stuff is a lot fancier and tastier than I can describe) but I keep going back to the mozzarella sandwich.

The name Il Massimo sounds fancy, but the restaurant is actually more like a cafe. You can order food from the deli and there are daily specials. I had the sun dried tomato penne with the chicken tomato soup. It was just the right amount and cooked well. They also serve a good looking lasagna which made my mouth water. It's a great spot for lunch as there is plenty of room to sit.

Massimo is about the nicest place in its corner of the financial district to take a book and get a soup and salad or half a sandwich, or a plate of lasagna on a cold summer day.  I've just gone there for lunch (sometimes late: they're open until 3 pm), but they have breakfast too.  The staff is warm and friendly.

They offer so much selection at lunchtime from sandwiches to salads to korean dishes to sushi.  But be careful because they charge by weight and the last time I went in there, my lunch box ended up to be $15 and I wasn't even totally full afterwards.  I guess I picked all the heavy food items.
To be honest, I came in not expecting much. And that's usually when something knocks your socks off, when you have no expectations or assumptions.

Not a fan! Our office is close by and so it is an easy place to grab food. We have been at this office location for a year and slowly one-by-one people at my office have seen things go on there that are not to our liking and can really ruin an appetite. It is kind of a standing office joke how terrible this place is. Some people still go and enjoy their diverse salad bar but it is hard to convince many people to go with you. The only saving grace is that they have poppy seed Costco muffins individually wrapped (cost marked up of course) so on rare occasion I will venture in their for one of those but that is about it. Not worth your time or money.
I walked in and the old guy just had his back turned to me and another customer, reading through a magazine. We waited literally 5 minutes in an awkward silence before I decided I will never return.

This poorly lit "Cafe" does have an espresso machine, but they won't make you a latte, even though there is a sign that says they offer them.  The two women in the back kitchen both saw me standing at the counter this morning, waiting to order, bot neither of them came out to help me.  Finally the other person waiting to order called back into the kitchen to have them come out.  The space is huge but rarely have I seen more than 3 people in there.  The salad bar is okay, but the lighting is so bad in there that the food looks rather unappealing.  It always seems like everyone is too busy to help you, and they could definitely benefit from being nicer to their customers.   Sadly, it is the closest place to my office and when I need a quick sandwich, it's where I go... however, the 5 minutes I spend waiting for someone to help me could be better spent walking up to the natural food store on Grant.  The turkey burger *is* good, but this place is just weird.

Mrs. T's is an enigma. Superficially, it's odd and misplaced, with outdated decor and furniture better suited to a retirement home in Boca Raton than this stately stretch of Montgomery Street in historic Jackson Square. The framed art would live comfortably in any cookie cutter dive or pizza joint.  Old school black and white photo of construction workers lunching on a skyscraper beam perched high above Manhattan? Check. Random tacky still life with lilies? Check. Western landscape in 80s oil colors with shiny gold frame? They've got that one, too.

I had the salad bar for the first time on 12/19 and I'm not going back.  Certain dishes tasted like they were from last week.  I prefer to walk the extra 3 blocks to Green Bar or Wildflower Café where the slad bar is always fresh.
The first time I tried this place I was so disappointed. No, I was seriously grossed out.
Pretty standard. Typical little cafe like a Lee's deli

The sandwiches are okay, just like your homemade sandwiches.  The Korean rice dish (bi bim bab) was horrible... I saw Mrs T (?) spraying some white powder over the food (god knows if it is garlic salt or MSG) but the dish has an unnatural explosion of flavor, and the rice was grey in color after it was heated up on the dirty grill...

Around the corner from where I work, Mrs. T's is my regular lunch spot, guaranteed to provide me with a delicious and healthy lunch. I actually love their fruit. It's as if they hand pick it, it's so fresh and delicious. Best watermelon around!

OK..I keep giving this place a chance, but I am consistently disappointed. And believe me, my expectations are low to begin with. I can deal with the unfriendly dude who runs the place, and my order is often incorrect, but overall the food is just very sub-standard. Clearly they are not using even minimally good ingredients and the place is filthy. I always take issue with employees not washing their hands between tasks involving clean up and cash transactions and food preparation/handling. Seriously gross. And I'm not that precious about cleanliness either...I will kiss a cat full on the mouth - no problem. But I almost walked out while watching my order to be prepared. I still ate it and got the full on heebie jeebies.

It's a cafeteria. The salad bar has a lot of korean/asian/ type stuff. It's no gourmet lunch place. And it ain't cheap either, but if you need something to eat, close to your office, this is it. It ain't Mickey D's either.

I work just a few blocks away from Mrs. T's.  And this place isn't that bad.  i mean I don't exactly live for anything they have there, and it's really no place special.  But on those work days when nothing seems to be going right and I decide that I deserve a cheeseburger, this is where I go.  It's no frills, but you get what you pay for.  And you don't get gut-punched by their prices like Pickles down the street.

I work a block away from Mrs. T's and we often call them with orders for our clients.  Frankly, just about every aspect of their customer service sucks, from their brusque phone manners and their lack of being willing to read back your order to their constant mistakes with orders and their speed of delivery (a half-hour is typical, for a couple of egg-and-bagel sandwiches).  If they were a block further away and Specialty's was a block closer, we'd never call Mrs. T's again.  If you're eating in, their sorry customer service might be less of an issue (although they're still pretty surly in person), but relying on them to understand a phoned-in order and get it to you correctly and in a reasonable amount of time is close to hopeless.
It's hump day, and my coworker was craving Korean food. (A korean craving korean food...go figure.)
I usually get the salad bar here.  I like that there is a wide variety of items on the salad bar.

I've pretty much only ever had breakfast here. I work at an office near here about a few times a month and I always get a toasted bagel with scrambled eggs, turkey or chicken and avocado to go. It's pretty good. Good enough for me to always order the same thing every time any way.

I work a block away from Mrs. T's and went there for lunch one time. They have a great salad bar where your can find different types of cold pastas, veggies and some good hot food like teriyaki chicken and egg roles. They have different items everyday and they also have a grill menu. My all time favorite though is their morning breakfast sandwich, its a little egg muffin with egg, cheese and bacon. Add tomato to it and it taste like heaven. The place could use a little more spirit to it, especially the staff but the food is worth it.

If ever a restaurant merited exactly 3 stars, nor more, no less, it is Mrs. T's.  I think honestly you could calibrate this site's reviews by stating canonically that Mrs. T's is the essence of 3-star-dom.  The decor is startlingly average.  It looks like a company cafeteria.  The food is startlingly average.  I had the steam table food, and everything tasted exactly like it should; no better, no worse.  The sushi was grocery store sushi.  The noodles were fine, but could have come from a box.  The brussel sprouts had a touch of character.  I would have been startled by how average the service and prices were, but fortunately for me, I had now calibrated my expectations and was able to make my saving throw to avoid being startled.

good food and love their Korean Be bim bab - the staffing is a bit strange and they could use a decorator. Sometimes they're a bit abrupt and sometimes their nice. I go here really because it's close to my office - but that's it

This place is great. A little dingy and a little weird maybe. And the guy behind the counter, who I assume must be Mr. T, always sorta makes me anxious when he barks orders back at this staff. But they make a mean Bacon and Avocado sandwich. And you can get hot tamales and other candy out of the jars by the cash register on a long day. I definitely recommend it for a work lunch.

Wow. $10 doesn't get you nearly as much at pay-by-weight salad/lunch bars as it used to, but the food here is good. There are a lot of healthy options, and several high quality hot dishes that change throughout the week.

Holy Salad Bar Batman!  Did you see sushi?!  Not to mention the thousand other items that this place offers.  I still have yet to try everything as the hot items are constantly rotating.  That's right, hot items at a salad bar.

Yum! Mrs. T's is a regular lunch spot for the Financial District crowd and it's good. For their salad bar, you can count on all kinds of pastas, salad fixings, fresh fruit, meatballs, tofu dishes, Vegetable and gyoza tempura and the list goes on. From my experience, everything is fresh and delicious.

It's just around the corner from work so it's easy to call in and pick up (like most people working 'round the area) We like the burgers, particularly the veggie one-pretty surprised that it had some nice little sauteed onions in there (I hate raw onions).
I've only eaten food from here because they have a deal with my office.  So when I have to work through lunch, these guys deliver.  That being said, I really like this place.

How complicated can getting breakfast in the morning be? Well when stepping into this place, the level of difficulty to get a bagel increases 10 fold. Flagging down the guy at the front (Mr. T, I presume) is damn near impossible when he's in the back kitchen lashing his employees (one of them probably being Mrs. T). And when you do get someones attention, you're conveniently ignored until ofcourse, Mr. T's ready to come to the front to take your order. As mentioned in other reviews, the $2 morning specials are good but saving a couple of bucks here against other neighborhood cafes is not worth it. Not to mention the fact that you have to double check everything you pull out from the drink cooler. I've pulled out expired year old juices several times before finally giving up on this place.

Great salad/pasta bar. Reminds me of some of the corner delis in NYC.  Good for quick lunch stop... Very clean lots of variety - they even have sliced up burritos.   They also have indoor seating and they take Visa - with no signatures under $25.... this might seem stupid but when your in a rush - one less thing to deal with.

Unless you are starving and in dire need of greasy eggs in the morning, I would stay clear of this place, at the very least for break fest. Their salad bar for lunch does save them from being completely worthless, with an amazing selection of food, and they have surprisingly good coffee. But the owner's vile attitude and disposition prevents any kind of good business to be possible, not to mention problems such as wrong orders, phone orders that take over half an hour to fill, burnt/overcooked food, over-greasy food, untoasted bagels, etc. You will often find yourself waiting for several minutes, completely ignored by the large staff that is in the kitchen avoiding you, most likely contemplating if and how their breakfast can be more greasy. Sadly, as long as your food can take, and as disappointing it can be, you will be even further surprised since the place will probably be empty.
People, this used to be my lunchtime jam.  I almost gave it five stars for pure warm glow nostalgia reasons, but even though it's awesome, a five star rating would be going a little overboard.
A hole-in-the-wall sandwich shop in Jackson Square, that serves decent lunch time fare.
Best place for fresh sushi. Very friendly staff, and service is quick, even if you sit at the sushi bar, and order from the kitchen

My friend and I decided to come check it out for lunch. We sat at the sushi boat area and mainly just ate from it. They do a few things fairly well, such as seared salmon and their sashimi cuts, but I was not impressed with any of their rolls.

We hopped in the place coz I didn't want to have a big lunch, I saw there was a floating boat sushi bar but the sushi is not covered, I kept skeptical about that, anyway, I ordered flied yam and I shared the CA rolls with my friend, yam was a lttle oily and rolls taste not bad. My friend's beef udon was ok. I found the dishes and the place were not clean, felt uncomfortsble afterward, I don't think I would take a risk again.

Its pretty good for lunch in downtown SF. The crowd gets going around 11:30am. I wouldn't go out of my way but its a decent place. The prices are fair. The service is good. The guy would always refill my tea. The hostess is nice. I would come here again but its not my go to sushi.
Womp womp.
The chicken teriyaki skewers were different. I enjoyed the Hawaii tuna rolls more. Prices were pretty decent for sushi. Right in the heart of the financial district.

I was still hungry and somehow craving for sashimi after downing a burger (it was a small burger, don't judge), and wandered into Sushi Umi. It was 2:30pm and the first floor was pretty empty except for some late lunch goers around the sushi boat counter. I was quickly greeted by 2 waitresses, handed a menu, and informed of their lunch specials.

Man, what a refreshing and tasty place to pop into in the smack-dab middle of the Financial District. I'm not a fan of the bustle of downtown, not to mention the thick of identical restaurants and cafes. It's great to have a family owned business in the FiDi amidst all the chains. It's pretty amazing to know that the people serving you at Sushi Umi, unlike many businesses around in the area, don't treat you like a head - instead, you're a friend. Most places in the Financial District get this wrong...Sushi Umi gets it right.

A business contact shared this find with me earlier this week. The rolls were inventive and tasty. A bit too much rice on the rolls, but the fish portions were fair to generous. A good lunch place for a weekday sushi craving.

Not sure what all the complain is about, but I like this place.  I'm not a fan of sushi especially raw, but I love the set lunches, especially the Hamachi kama.  For $12.50, it comes with a piece of Hamachi kama, some rice, some salad, 4 pieces of California roll & a miso soup.  The dressing on the salad is delicious & the sauce for the Hamachi kama is tasty as well.  This is like the better version of Japanese food around the financial district, but the price is a tiny bit steeper than the others.
I really liked their chicken skewers. Meat was cooked perfectly! It was very savory.

Basic rolls and sashimi are delightful. Me and some coworkers went for lunch on a Friday upstairs. Service was quick and attentive. Food was delicious and came to table after 5 min. I highly recommend the Garden Roll with fried asparagus. I don't ordinarily like fried food, but this added the perfect crunch.

I assume this place must be housed in San Francisco's skinniest office building. At least it looks like it from across the street, and this nondescript Japanese spot takes up the first two floors like some Ginza-style eatery where it would be surrounded by identical sushi establishments. But this is not the Ginza, and there isn't a geisha waitress in sight ready to walk on your back. No, this business couldn't survive in Tokyo, and frankly, I'm surprised it's been able to survive here since it's just so unequivocally mediocre in a city filled with great sushi places. Only not in the FiDi and therein lies the conundrum for any office worker looking for a little fresh hamaichi to get him through a long work day.

Came here few months ago with a coworker. Sat down for the a-la-carte sushi. As soon as I sat down I knew this was a bad idea. If you've had any kind of decent sushi before you could tell some of them have been sitting there for quite awhile. It was really gross.

It's a small place that's not too busy, but they do have some really nice sushis to select from on a rotating boat platform thing. Its yummy and the service was amazing! Come here to see your sushi past by your eyes on mini boats drifting before your eyes! Don't forget to checkin into Yelp on your mobile device through the app and you could get a coupon. I got one for a free Miso soup :D

Never going here again. Just paid $17 for the TINIEST 12 piece sashimi combo in the history of the world. I know this is the Financial District and everything including the air you breathe here is expensive, but 3 1/2 bites worth of meh quality fish is a crime.

Quick and easy financial district lunch.  If I have a colleague, friend, or business contact that I want to have a simple lunch with, this is my go to place.  Not really sure why the string of super negative reviews... the Sushi here isn't anything to write home about, but it's generally pretty decent and the service is fast (their lunch business is all about turning tables).  Environment is casual and I always like the ability to grab items of interest as they float on by.

I was craving for sushi so BB&me decided to go there cuz it was on our way. Didn't eat much but our lunch end up 70$,,, Sad face... :-( I told my self once a while it's k to spend 70$ for lunch... BUT fish were so old and too dried up to be worth$70+
OMFG! Another 100% Chinese BS -Kaiten Su-shit!
It's like your a hungry bear waiting on your bait to float by.... In my opinion I like

Avoid like the plague!  The sushi going around the sushi boat totally didn't look fresh at all.  The chicken teriyaki bento you can't order a la carte just the teriyaki, and it's yakitori not chicken breast or thighs.  The main focus here is the sushi not menu items.  The service wasn't very helpful at all either.  I guess this place gets busy only due to its cheap prices.

Sub par sushi, slow delivery, and they forgot miso, chop sticks, napkins, spicy mayo, AND A SPICY TUNA ROLL!. We got the money back for that roll but the rest of the food wasn't even that good. Avoid this place!
All around a fan of the place in terms of sushi, udon, and service!  I guess delivery isn't the best from reading the other reviews, but eating in sure wasn't disappointing.

I find this to be a decent sushi place for when you're in a hurry or even if you want to linger.  The staff is very friendly and if you don't find what you're craving floating on the boats, just ask and they'll make it for you.  I've never dined upstairs, only enjoyed the Sushi boats and have never been disappointed.

I was happy to call an order in and pick it up for lunch. I work in Soma so there are very few sushi options out there... I drove over and the hungry me decided to park in the loading zone. I paid the meter thinking that maybe I'm lucky? Anyway, I came in, paid for it, it still wasn't ready so I hopped over to the walgreens next door. When I came back, my car was gone! Towed! So I went in to the sushi place to pick up my lunch and asked them if they had seen a car out front get towed. They looked at me in astonishment saying they asked their customers if that was their car as they called to have it towed.... What? Wow...  I'm not sure if they get money for every time they act like DPT but they will never get money from me again. And I hope this means for you reading this, too!

Boyfriend and I went here pretty late one evening. It's usually a lunch place so it was absolutely dead. But we had good service and the food was super tasty. I would go back for lunch but I'm sure they're packed!

Maybe in the past this place was bad, but I didn't find anything wrong with it.  The sushi boat experience is excellent if you want fresh variety quickly.  Price was OK.  Maybe a bit high, but didn't feel it was too extreme for what I got.  Plan on $15 minimum with no drink.  Also, the prices are listed by plate type.  It's not as easy as if they just used colors because it's by sort of designs, but it's pretty straightforward once you figure it out.
Umm.... No.
The lunch specials are a great value. Service was good and my friend got several refills on her soda. I will definitely be back.

I'm already not a big fan of sushi places in the FD, but since some of my coworkers said this place wasn't too bad the last time they came, I figured they can't go wrong with salmon teriyaki and california rolls.
This review relates to a bad DELIVERY experience, which is completely my fault. I didn't realize that it was a financial district sushi place until after I ordered and ate.
Best spot for sushi in FiDi.  I don't know how anyone can complain.  Better than anywhere else in SF.  Fish is very fresh.  Prices totally reasonable!!!!

I like this place and come here often for the sushi boat.  Nice presentation, nice variety, way better than Isobune in Japantown.  The sushi is fresh and it's fun watching the chef at work. If sushi boat is not your thing you can go sit upstairs in the restaurant area and just order what you want via menu. They have a salmon kama, which I adore, but I  haven't seen offered in any other restaurants, most just offer hamachi kama (which this place has as well). Service is pretty good even when the restaurant is busy the girls always run around refilling your tea. Prices are pretty decent as well. This place is a stone's throw away from my job so it's a quick and easy place to come for a quick, affordable and tasty lunch. BRAVO, Sushi Umi, bravo!

Thought I had ordered enough food for a bunch of us, but when they delivered it, it was so not enough. The delivery guy ran right back to the restaurant, and within 20 mins was back with a huge platter of sushi. Great service.

I go to this place for the sushi boat lunch at least once a week.  It's good although I would say a little on the expensive side if you're not paying attention to what you grab.  They fill your tea as soon as you take a sip out of the glass.  Fish is always fresh - never had a problem.

Poor quality sushi when you dine in unless you order straight from the sushi chef. I feel like they leave that sushi rotating on their the whole day until someone picks it up, which of course causes it to dry up and lose it's freshness. The take out is not so impressive either. I ordered the $13 3 amigos roll and the portion was small and though the quality was better than on the sushi boat, it still wasn't great. Just overall not a good sushi place.
It is better than decent sushi, is fairly priced for the FiDi, and has fast and friendly service.

I eat here all the time.  Come early (right before 12 p.m.) if you want to get a seat at the sushi boat counter.  One of my favorite selections is spicy tuna in a one-half avocado.  YUM!  Usually costs me about $20-$25 per person for a really big sushi lunch.  I have eaten at some of the fancier sushi counters and spent about $80 or so.  I would much rather eat at Sushi Umi!

Their food is never that great, slow series, miss order, and food never served at the timely manner for group people. Most of us almost finished our food, and some people didn't even get their order yet.
Here's the deal.  It is decent food.  The Udon is darn good, maybe the best I have had in SF, for sure in FiDi.  The sushi is just fine, but not the best sushi you have ever had.
I order from Specialty's all the time, but this particular location gets only one star because they fail at the #1 reason to go to Specialty's at all: CONVENIENCE.
I came across this place because I was doing some work in the area. Not only are the employees friendly and nice the pastries and drinks are fantastic.

Straightforward and easy process to put your order in. I mostly do online ordering for lunch and start walking to pick up my sack o' sandwich. However, on more than a couple of occasions, rare as it might be, the cookie or bag of chips I ordered is the wrong kind.
Amazing cookies. Try their freshly baked  white chocolate hazelnut cookie or dark chocolate walnut cookie when they are still warm. They are just too too good.

I often order group lunches from Specialties and they are always so quick and courteous.  Ordering online for meetings and for my personal lunches is super easy, especially when using the customization tool. The food is always ready a few minutes early.  The cookies are ridiculously good and the salads are tasty.

One star for no other reason than these folks are dishonest.  I wondered why a sandwich listed on the menu for $8.99 could end up costing $10.27 when tax is below ten percent.  Answer: they tack on what they call a 4 percent "service charge," which they say is "in part, to help offset the additional regulatory costs of doing business in the city of San Francisco."  (That doesn't include the bag fee, which they add separately).
Great sandwiches and soup. Recommend ordering online to avoid waiting forever to get your food. Good prices too.

Specialty's is getting (for me anyway) to be like ABC stores in Hawaii. There's one on every corner or in every FIDI building. Everyone has their favs here. Mine is the Hot Alby. . . It's a sloppy mess of a tuna melt. . . I love it. . . Oh, and don't forget the cookies. . . hot cookies. . . Oh did I say that twice?

Okay, so I think THESE are the best cookies in the city!!!  It was previously another place but i've tasted them more recently and I wasn't impressed, then days later went to Specialty's and they had better ones than anyone before!  Specialty's is WHERE IT'S AT!!!
Looovveeee the Caprese but the assembly line is pretty strict on the basil.

What the hell happened to this place?  In the past, I've come here and ordered sandwiches.  In and out within 5 minutes.  Today, I ordered my turkey pesto and waited, waited and waited.  There were a lot of people in the store waiting for their food too!  Someone messed up another person's order so all the tracks stopped until they fixed it.
Whenever I go to San Francisco, and walk on Market St. I always buy their cookies and baked goods here.
Deflation.
Specialty's is my favorite mid-day pick me up. I'm a sucker for warm, delicious chocolate chunk cookies.

ordered a bun cake after 12 noon ( when you know half of everything is gone) and went to pick it up. however, it was gone-lol. they had went to pick it up from another store near by, but that was going to run in to my lunch window. so the MGR (best man ever) said he would have some one run it over to my office. and sure enough he did. THANK YOU. huge help
I got the lunch box which comes with a turkey , apple, chips and of course a cookie. Pretty satisfying meal.

FiDi workers- Please order your lunch by using their website! By doing that, you can just walk in, look at the little carts on the left side as you walk in and find your order in the brown paper bag. This will save you at least 10-15 minutes of waiting time! Trust me.

Ok. I love their chocolate chip cookies. That's why I am giving them four stars. Seriously, I know everyone and their mom raves about it. But it is so good. So chocolately and chewy. It's gooey. It melts in your mouth. It's as good as a cookie can get. But I'm not a huge chocolate fan, so one chocolate chip cookie will do for me.
I used to love Specialty's when I worked near their Spear street location. I loved that you could order online and then run and pick it up when you were busy.
The Hot Hammer is tasty but messy.  Gets soggy quick, so eat it soon.  Don't forget the yummy warm cookies!
Sandwiches are packed and squished together so tight you can't even tell there is bread.  Too bad as the bread is good.  By the time i open the paper wrapper all i find is $8 worth of mush and water.
Cookie porn.  That about says it all.  For those who aren't satisfied with soft, melting chocolate chip cookies -- these babies are double thick and a meal unto itself.

Cookies, cookies, cookies! I sprinted to the register, rudely cutting others in the process (#honeybadger), and quietly demanded "Me want cookie!" Either I like to imitate the cookie monster or my grammar skills disappear once the aroma of baked chocolate chubbymakers invade my nose.
I used to love Specialty's cookies but for some reason over the past year, they are not good at all. :( Really bummed b/c they were my go-to place for cookies.

now, i don't consider myself a religious woman, but OH SWEET MOTHER OF GOD ... i took one bite of the dark chocolate peanut butter and i think i saw jesus. he was surrounded by little angels and lights, and told me to keep chewing when all i wanted to do was run my happy ass to the back, take an IV and inject that raw dough directly into my blood stream to get it all into my body a little bit sooner.
Three words......Carrot Bran Muffins.......Boom!  Love this place and the service always gets my day off to great start.  Keep up the good work!

I've been craving a semi-sweet chocolate chip cookie from Specialty's for weeks! The one by the montgomery bart station is closed for remodeling right now so I had to trek to this location. I'm so glad I did because the cookie was just as delicious as I remembered. The perfect afternoon treat while I'm still in holiday mode and can happily ignore the calories.
Always out of everything.  Going here is a waste of time.
Specialty's bread makes me salivate.  I've definitely come here for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Different things of course. But for the bread. Every. Single. Time. I love carbs.
OHMYDEARGODTHECINNAMONBUNSARETODIEFOR.

This is for my experience yesterday. Normally I go around 11am-12pm and get a chocolate chip cookie. Yesterday I didn't make it until 3pm and my usual side-window server (the veteran) wasn't there. Instead it was a girl I've never seen before (vaguely tallish, hispanic, just so you can watch out in the future). While I was ordering she turned away and sneezed into her hand. Yes, directly into her hand. She didn't wash her hands or put gloves on. Instead she wiped them off on a sheet of cookie paper and left the scrunched-up ball on the counter. Then she picked up my cookie (again only using a sheet of cookie paper) and gave it to me.
Great soup and tasty roast beef sandwich. This is a second time I have tried Specialty's. If you want quality food with a reasonable price in SF, this is definitely a place.

I go to this Specialties randomly for cookies that I love but are HORRIBLY bad for you (check the calorie count, yikes!) .. The cookies get a 5star rating from me. HOWEVER, I've now went 2 times within the past week for a salad and BOTH times I've had issues, therefore, I don't plan to return for any food, only cookies since those are usually already on the tray for purchase.
Review #1219. Expedient service with full window of baked food. The aroma drew you in as you walked past and it was hard to miss and not stop by and to pick up some goodies.

Got the Cobb sandwich, $7.29 of freshly roasted turkey with bacon. I know it's 1046 calories, but I'm not having one of those every day. It gave me a bacon aftertaste, though (which is not always good).

Meh. I've never found a salad or sandwich at Specialty's that was very satisfying or memorable. But then I got into their Cobb sandwich... until I found out it had 1040 calories and 62 GRAMS OF FAT (compare to a Big Mac at 540 cal/29 grams fat). Terrifying!

My fallback option for those days when I have forgotten or didn't have the time to pack a lunch, as this location is across the street from my office.  Cobb sandwich and a cookie and I am a happy me.  Love that I can order online and get a text when it is ready.  The turkey apple brie is also good and the salads, particularly the one with berries and goat cheese look tempting (my officemates have ordered that one often).

The food here is good, but best if you order in advance.  I was walking on my way to work and decided to order a sandwich.  Wow it took a while for them to make it.  Good thing was was early going to work, or else I would have canceled my order.

any business that does not allow customers to order from their website without registering first is ridiculous. i have never heard of a business that refuses to allow for a customer to place an order without registering, so rather than register, i attempted to call the store directly, and they refused to take my order. i think i'll go to foccacia market instead.

I've recently fallen in love with their veggie sandwich. It is served on herbed bread (AH-MAY-ZINGGGGGGG!) and stacked super high with fresh veggies. They throw lettuce on top of lettuce, sprouts, tomatoes, avocado, onions, cheese (Swiss & provolone) and peppers up in there. You can customize it any way you want. They also use mustard and mayo so be sure to tell them if you don't want something in there.
Just your average soup spot in San Francisco. Nothing soup-er fancy... hehe

7/8 update - they put back the lettuce!?  Salads are big again.  Still one of the best deals for organic lettuce salad out there.  For soups, however, I recommend you cross the street and go to Max's in the B of A building - better soup, better prices.

Short preface, I love soup. I used to wake my college roomate up in the middle of the night and make her go get soup with me. We call it "feeling soupy". Anyway, I say this with great regret because of my soulful soupy love, this might be the worlds WORST soup I've ever had.

I got the Mexican Chicken Tortilla Soup and found it to be thick and salty, although tasty. The consistency was like chili, maybe because of all of the cheese. In fact, I know it had to be... I'll move on to the other soup selections for the next time.
Yummy! Curry butternut squash perfect for a cold day ! Was delish along with some bread. The guy that works here is great always makes me smile. I recommend!!
The salads are prepared nicely and the split pea soup is tasty.  The cabo salad is very good. Great to have this option when it's cold outside.
Yummy!

Im from San Diego where they have real chicken soup. This is paste with chips. Where the F can u get real chicken soup in this town when ur sick? I don't want comfort food, i want real soup.. Whatever they said on the menu- no way. I just paid $40 to get two large soups delivered. I haven't eaten in two days and now im thinking i should have gotten Anny's at the liquor store
I was feeling under the weather today, so found SF Soup Company on the lookout for chicken soup (which is hard to find in this area).

Was a cold day,when I looking for a good place to have a lunch, I thought well, today is a good day to eat soup. I took my smartphone and start the search, when I found the SF Soup Company, it's ok let's try them. When I entered thought, yes this place is cool, and started to read the menu, when one kind waiter asked me: Would you like to try any flavor? I said of course, and try 3 kind flavors.

I usually like SF Soup Company for its salads more than its soup, but their large salad is HUGE ! (which is good if you're a big eater). So today, I orderd a small Cabo Chicken salad.  Strange thing is that small and large salads are charged the large salad price. How does that make any sense?
I dont have soup very often but when I do its Sf soup company. its a sf must.
My go-to place for soup and salad.. I love the Asian Chicken salad with meduim dressing.  The staff is friendly and knows my name.
I have walked into this place several times and each time I turn and walk out.

The corn chowder and chicken soup are ok, nothing too spectacular. I needed soup  because I was feeling under the weather and it was the nearest and fastest way to get soup in the area. They also have other types of soups which is a plus; however the portions aren't worth the price.
Great salads here. I got the Cabo Chicken Salad  and asked to add tofu and beets. Fresh, filling, and delicious. Will definitely try their soups next time. Great friendly service.

Soup.  Sometimes it's just what we need in life to feel better. After all, soup is just plain good.  And the soup here is super good.  Grandma Mary's Chicken Noodle Soup on a cold, rainy day is just what the doctor ordered. He really did. I would caution against ordering some of the more "experimental" offerings on the menus because every time I do, I always regret it. Stick with the basics here, and you'll be on the mend in no time flat.

I work directly across the street and first started coming here just out of convenience. Now that I've tried other mediocre soups around the neighborhood, I truly appreciate the freshness of the SF Soup Co!

I think I'm really a fan simply because they're so conveniently close to my office.   I can grab a tomato bisque and be back at my desk five minutes later.   They have some tasty soups although I ordered a salad once and wasn't particularly impressed.   I felt totally gypped with the amount of salad dressing.   Then again, I typically drown my salad in dressing, so I'm probably the one that's got an issue, not the salad.    Still, I typically just grab a soup and go.   I don't love their soup, but I've seldom been disappointed.
It's okay...

You can't just call proclaim yourself the Soup Company of San Francisco without some darn good soup. Well, I guess you could but you'd look like a fool. San Fran Soup Company deserves the title very much so though because they are absolutely, fantastically delicious! Think soups as delicious as the soup nazi's on Seinfeld but instead of the mean guy behind the counter it is a pleasure every time you come in! Yeah, that good!
